questionOriginal: Where do people living with a substance use disorder go for information on treatment and recovery services?
questionText: Where do people living with a substance use disorder go for information on treatment and recovery services?
answerOriginal:
The Vermont Department of Health has launched VTHelplink, a new, single source clearinghouse for Vermonters to receive free, confidential and personalized information and referrals to substance use prevention, treatment and recovery services throughout the state.

VTHelplink features a call center of trained staff and clinicians. Callers can get information, referrals, resources and educational materials on substance use for themselves, family and friends, or on behalf of clients.

The VTHelplink website has information resources and an online screening tool to help Vermonters learn about treatment options that meet their needs. People can also securely chat online with call center staff through the website.

The system also includes an appointment board designed to increase accessibility of treatment appointments by tracking availability by level of service (for example, residential treatment) and population (for example, people who are pregnant).

Hereâs how you can reach VTHelplink:

Dial 802-565-LINK (5465). The call center is open 8:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. weekdays, and 8:00 a.m to 6:00 p.m. weekends and holidays, 365 days per year.

Visit vthelplink.org.

questionOriginal: How can I take care of myself, my family, or friends with the stress from COVID-19?
questionText: How can I take care of myself, my family, or friends with the stress from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Feeling anxious, confused, overwhelmed or powerless is common during an infectious disease outbreak. Taking care of yourself, your friends, and your family can help you cope with stress. Helping others cope with their stress can also make your community stronger.

  • Take breaks from watching, reading, or listening to news stories, including social media. Hearing about the pandemic repeatedly can be upsetting.

  • Take care of your body. Take deep breaths, stretch, or meditate. Try to eat healthy, well-balanced meals, exercise regularly, get plenty of sleep, and avoid alcohol and drugs.

  • Make time to unwind. Try to do some other activities you enjoy.

  • Connect with others. Talk with people you trust about your concerns and how you are feeling.

Find more information on coping with COVID-19 stress, including resources for local help, self-care, suicide prevention, and domestic violence.

Find more tips for coping with stress from the CDC, including how to help children cope with stress.

Need support right now?

  • Call your local mental health crisis line

  • Text VT to 741741

  • Call 2-1-1 or 1-866-652-4636

  • Contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline or call 1-800-273-8255

  • For multilingual support, call 800-985-5990 or text TalkWithUs to 66746

questionOriginal: What should families do if they are not able to get formula, diapers, or other baby necessities?
questionText: What should families do if they are not able to get formula, diapers, or other baby necessities?
answerOriginal:
Families can call Help Me Grow-VT at 2-1-1 ext. 6 to be directed to services in their area that may be able to assist with formula, diapers, or other necessities.

Vermont WIC provides healthy foods, nutrition education, and breastfeeding support to pregnant and postpartum Vermonters and caregivers of infants and children under 5. Vermont WIC is open and invites new and returning families to join. If your family financial circumstances have changed due to a job loss or reduced hours, you could be eligible for WIC.

WIC has made a few changes to keep families and staff safe during the COVID-19 pandemic. All appointments are being done by phone and breastfeeding classes are offered online.

Apply for WIC online or text VTWIC to 855-11. You can also connect with WIC in your area.

Food banks and food shelves may be resources for families not eligible for WIC. Find more information on food access from Hunger Free Vermont.

Find more resources for families with children.

questionOriginal: How can I report a person or business who is violating the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order?
questionText: How can I report a person or business who is violating the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order?
answerOriginal:
The Department of Public Safety and the Vermont State Police recommended to Vermont municipal leaders and law-enforcement executives that enforcement of the Governorâs Stay Home, Stay Safe Order be handled mainly through education and voluntary compliance.

  • For concerns about businesses or lodging facilities that are violating the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order, use the Department of Public Safetyâs non-compliance complaint form to gather more information.

  • For concerns or complaints about restaurants, use the Health Departmentâs online sanitation complaint form, email FoodLodging@vermont.gov, or call 802-863-7221.

  • For employees to report alleged safety or health hazards, use the Vermont Occupational Safety and Health Administrationâs (VOSHA) confidential safety complaint form.

  • For complaints regarding individuals who are failing to self-quarantine, as required, please call your local law-enforcement agency.

Read the Attorney Generalâs Enforcement Directive.

Find out more about what the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order means to Vermonters.

Find sector-specific guidance from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development for details on which businesses are open.

questionOriginal: Does the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order mean I can be arrested or will need special papers if I leave my home?
questionText: Does the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order mean I can be arrested or will need special papers if I leave my home?
answerOriginal:
Enforcement of the Governor's Stay Home, Stay Safe Order will be mainly be done through education and voluntary compliance.

  • The Order does not close roads and does not establish roadblocks or checkpoints.

  • Motor vehicle and pedestrian traffic will continue as Vermonters do outdoor activities that are allowed and travel to and from businesses (including grocery stores and pharmacies) and other entities that are allowed to operate under the Order.

  • There will not be motor vehicle stops or people detained for questioning about their travel, but law enforcement officers may be reminding people of the Order if they see groups gathering or businesses operating in violation of the Order.

Read the latest updates to the Stay Home, Stay Safe Executive Order.

There will not be motor vehicle stops or people detained for questioning about their travel, but law enforcement officers may be reminding people of the Order if they see groups gathering or businesses operating in violation of the Order.


Read the latest updates to the Stay Home, Stay Safe Executive Order.

questionOriginal: Can I buy or sign a long-term lease (more than 30 days) for a new apartment or house?
questionText: Can I buy or sign a long-term lease (more than 30 days) for a new apartment or house?

questionOriginal: Are sports and outdoor activities allowed?
questionText: Are sports and outdoor activities allowed?
answerOriginal:
We encourage Vermonters to go outside and enjoy the fresh air. Exercise, outdoor activities, and taking in Vermontâs natural beauty is important for our mind and bodies.

Businesses, non-profit and government entities that support or offer outdoor recreation and outdoor fitness activities with low or no direct physical contact can open on May 7. These include, but are not limited to, state and municipal parks, recreation associations, trail networks, golf courses, big game check stations and guided expeditions.

Campgrounds, marinas and beaches are not permitted to open at this time. Find up-to-date information on outdoor recreation and campgrounds from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.

Contact sports and games should not be played at this time.

We can safely continue to enjoy outdoor activities with these measures:

  • Stay close to home. Find local outdoor recreation areas and consider day trips that are close to home. Only drive with members of your household.

  • Take health and safety precautions. Keep the virus from spreading by staying at least 6 feet apart from other people outside of your household, washing or sanitizing your hands, and staying home when you are sick.

  • Bring a cloth face mask with you. Put a cloth face mask or covering on if you encounter other people and stop to chat or if you are on a crowded trail or bike path.

  • Be cautious and choose low-risk activities to avoid injury. This will help lower the burden on our hospitals and health care system.

  • Respect signs for closed areas, trails and land. Check Trail Finder to find out if your trail is currently open before you visit. Call ahead or check websites for information on outdoor recreation facilities before you head out.

  • Choose no-contact sports: For example, biking, hiking, horseback riding, tennis, boating and golfing. Outdoor basketball courts may be open to shoot hoops, but signage should be posted prohibiting contact games. Do not share sports equipment with people outside of your household.

  • Check for ticks and wear an EPA-registered tick repellent. When youâre out walking or spending time in your backyard, remember that ticks are active this time of year. Find out how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites.

Find out more about outdoor recreation and COVID-19 from the Vermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation and the Vermont Fish and Wildlife Department.

Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

questionOriginal: Can I get COVID-19 from my pets or other animals? Can animals carry the virus on their skin or fur?
questionText: Can I get COVID-19 from my pets or other animals? Can animals carry the virus on their skin or fur?
answerOriginal:
According to the CDC, at this time, there is no evidence that animals play a large role in spreading the virus that causes COVID-19, and no evidence that the COVID-19 virus can spread to people from the skin, fur or hair of pets. Based on the limited information available at this time, the risk of animals spreading COVID-19 to people is considered to be low. A small number of pets have been reported to be infected with the virus that causes COVID-19, mostly after contact with people with COVID-19.

Pets have other types of coronaviruses that can make them sick, like canine and feline coronaviruses. These other coronaviruses cannot infect people and are not related to the current COVID-19 pandemic.

However, since animals can spread other diseases to people, itâs always a good idea to practice healthy habits around pets and other animals, such as washing your hands and maintaining good hygiene. Find more information on staying safe and healthy around animals including pets from the CDC.

Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

questionOriginal: Is there a medicine I can take to prevent or treat COVID-19?
questionText: Is there a medicine I can take to prevent or treat COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
As reports appear in the news of certain drugs being potentially used for treatment or prevention of COVID-19, the Vermont Department of Health strongly urges caution.

Though the anti-malarial drugs chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, among others, have been widely discussed as potential treatments, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said there are no data currently available from randomized clinical trials that would inform how these drugs could be used to treat COVID-19.

In fact, there are significant potential risks to taking such drugs, including death.

Health officials remind Vermonters that most people who get COVID-19 can manage their symptoms at home with rest, drinking fluids and taking fever-reducing medication. Talk to your health care provider before taking any substance alleged to prevent or treat COVID-19.

Providers should only prescribe these drugs for individuals with diagnosed conditions, and not for prevention, to help maintain the supply for Vermonters who need them.

questionOriginal: Should I avoid contact with pets or other animals if I am sick with COVID-19?
questionText: Should I avoid contact with pets or other animals if I am sick with COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you are sick with COVID-19 (either suspected or confirmed by a test), avoid contact with your pets and other animals, just like you would around other people.

  • When possible, have another member of your household care for your pets while you are sick.

  • Avoid contact with your pet, including petting, snuggling, being kissed or licked, and sharing food or bedding.

  • If you must care for your pet or be around animals while you are sick, wear a cloth face mask or covering and wash your hands before and after you interact with them.

Learn more about what to do if you have animals from the CDC.

Find more information on preparing for your pet from the CDC.

Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

questionOriginal: Is it safe to go to the hospital?
questionText: Is it safe to go to the hospital?
answerOriginal:
If you are having symptoms of a more serious medical condition, such as heart attack or stroke, it is important to get medical care right away. Call 9-1-1, go to the emergency room, or call your doctor if your symptoms are not life-threatening.

It is safe to seek care at Vermont hospitals. They have measures in place to protect patients in the hospital from getting COVID-19. This includes separating patients with COVID-19 from other patients. There is a greater risk to staying at home if you're experiencing symptoms of a serious medical condition than going to the hospital.

As of May 4, health care providers may also begin to do some clinic visits, diagnostic imaging, and outpatient surgeries and procedures again â as long as they have a minimal impact on inpatient hospital bed capacity and personal protective equipment (PPE). This does not include elective surgeries that require staying at the hospital, which are not permitted at this time. Read the Governorâs press release for details.

questionOriginal: Can I volunteer to help with the Stateâs response to COVID-19?
questionText: Can I volunteer to help with the Stateâs response to COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Yes, people with medical and health care skills and those with other needed skills can sign up for volunteer assistance to support the stateâs response to COVID-19. We currently have a contact tracing team in place, but these are other ways you can help.

People with medical or other health care backgrounds are needed to support the health care providers responding to the COVID-19 pandemic. Vermontâs Medical Reserve Corps units are community-based groups of volunteers who supplement local emergency and public health resources with their existing skills.

Sign up with the Vermont Medical Reserve Corps if you:

  • Are a licensed and certified health care professional

  • Have health, mental health, or other types of clinical or professional experience

  • Have health care administrative experience, such as with medical data entry or language translators

  • Have worked with displaced individuals, such as homeless shelter programs

Vermont has eased licensing requirements for the purposes of aiding this emergency response. Physicians, physician assistants and podiatrists can learn more on the Board of Medical Practice website. Other medical professionals, including nurses and osteopathic physicians, can learn more on the Office of Professional Regulation's website.

Other individuals who have needed skills (for example, drivers, food service, construction, IT, security, skilled trades, etc.), can sign up at vermont.gov/volunteer and indicate their expertise and availability.

Vermonters can also contribute to blood banks, food banks, and other emergency supply efforts. The American Red Cross of Northern New England faces a severe blood shortage and many local food banks and other community organizations are in need of support and donations of supplies.

Give blood: Learn how to safely donate blood with the American Red Cross.

Support your local Foodbank by donating online or you can text GIVEHEALTH to 85511. The Vermont Foodbank can help if you need it.

You can also help your neighbors â older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have underlying medical conditions should stay home as much as possible. Go shopping for a neighbor or someone else in need, keep an older neighbor company by phone or at a safe distance. When volunteering please follow the guidelines on being a good neighbor.

questionOriginal: How can community helpers and volunteers keep from getting sick with COVID-19?
questionText: How can community helpers and volunteers keep from getting sick with COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Making sure neighbors have what they need is crucial, but we need to make sure helpers and volunteers are still taking precautions to protect our most vulnerable Vermonters. Common sense practices can go a long way while Vermonters take care of each other.

The Vermont Department of Health recommends any volunteers bringing items to those who need to stay home:

  • Keep a distance of 6 feet away.

  • Avoid entering the personâs home.

  • Wear a cloth face mask or covering.

  • Wash your hands regularly.

  • Avoid touching your face and cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.

  • Stop doing community support work immediately if you feel sick or find out you have had contact with someone who is sick.

  • Keep a list of anyone you come into close contact with in case contact tracing is required.

  • Wear clean gloves when handling items that may be given to people with a weaker immune system, and when you are close to someone who may be sick.
answerText:
Making sure neighbors have what they need is crucial, but we need to make sure helpers and volunteers are still taking precautions to protect our most vulnerable Vermonters. Common sense practices can go a long way while Vermonters take care of each other.
The Vermont Department of Health recommends any volunteers bringing items to those who need to stay home:


Keep a distance of 6 feet away.


Avoid entering the personâs home.


Wear a cloth face mask or covering.


Wash your hands regularly.


Avoid touching your face and cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.


Stop doing community support work immediately if you feel sick or find out you have had contact with someone who is sick.


Keep a list of anyone you come into close contact with in case contact tracing is required.


Wear clean gloves when handling items that may be given to people with a weaker immune system, and when you are close to someone who may be sick.

questionOriginal: Is there universal (widespread) testing being done at group living facilities?
questionText: Is there universal (widespread) testing being done at group living facilities?
answerOriginal:
In Vermont, additional measures are being taken to slow the spread of COVID-19 in certain types of group living facilities. This includes nursing homes, corrections facilities, residential homes for people with disabilities, residential treatment centers, assisted living facilities, state psychiatric care facilities, and homeless shelters. In the event of a COVID-19 positive staff or resident, universal testing of all staff and residents is offered at these facilities. Staff and residents may decline testing, and facilities may decline universal testing.

Additionally, when a person tests positive at a skilled nursing facility, sequential testing is offered to those who tested negative during the universal testing.

questionOriginal: Why is race and ethnicity now included in reported data on COVID-19 cases?
questionText: Why is race and ethnicity now included in reported data on COVID-19 cases?
answerOriginal:
The Health Department is now including data about race and ethnicity on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. We recognized the need to include this information to help us understand how Vermonters were being affected by COVID-19, but in our earlier efforts to respond to the pandemic, race and ethnicity data was not always collected for each patient. A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont.

Health equity exists when all people have a fair and just opportunity to be healthy â especially those who have experienced socioeconomic disadvantage, historical injustice, and other systemic inequalities. Therefore, our epidemiology team collaborated with Vermont Information Technology Leaders (VITL) to cross-reference medical records to gain more robust race information about COVID-19 cases in Vermont.

We can use this data to help to prevent the spread of illness, improve care for patients, and present a more complete picture of how COVID-19 may be affecting everyone in Vermont.

questionOriginal: Who is getting tested for COVID-19 in Vermont?
questionText: Who is getting tested for COVID-19 in Vermont?
answerOriginal:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to be tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic for referral to a test site.

Health care providers are encouraged to order a test for any child or adult who is showing symptoms of COVID-19, even if their symptoms are mild.

We ramping up our testing capabilities to conduct 1,000 tests a day â or 7,000 tests a week. We know that with increased testing we are likely to see a rise in positive cases, and we are prepared to handle such a scenario. A new Testing and Tracing Task Force has been created to guide and oversee this process.

Testing is currently available for:

  • Any adult or child with symptoms of COVID-19 â even if their symptoms are mild â who has been referred for testing by their doctor.

  • Long-term care facilities and other group living settings:

    • All residents and staff in group living settings, where there has been a single positive test. This includes nursing homes, assisted living facilities, prisons, and certain high-density residential buildings.
    • If there is a person who has tested positive with COVID-19 at a skilled nursing facility, they can be retested at 3 days, 7 days, 10 days and 14 days after the initial test. This is to help prevent community-wide outbreaks. *For all sites, regardless of whether a person has tested positive, testing is offered at intake, discharge, and for certain residents who require regular care outside of the facility.

  • Staff at correctional facilities

  • Any Vermonter without symptoms can be tested at a pop-up site without a doctorâs referral, but registration for testing is required. Regular test collection locations still require a doctorâs referral.

    • The following groups are encouraged to get tested at these sites: health care workers, first responders (EMS, fire, and law enforcement), child care providers currently serving essential workers, and anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
answerText:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to be tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic for referral to a test site.
Health care providers are encouraged to order a test for any child or adult who is showing symptoms of COVID-19, even if their symptoms are mild.
We ramping up our testing capabilities to conduct 1,000 tests a day â or 7,000 tests a week. We know that with increased testing we are likely to see a rise in positive cases, and we are prepared to handle such a scenario. A new Testing and Tracing Task Force has been created to guide and oversee this process.
Testing is currently available for:


Any adult or child with symptoms of COVID-19 â even if their symptoms are mild â who has been referred for testing by their doctor.


Long-term care facilities and other group living settings:

All residents and staff in group living settings, where there has been a single positive test. This includes nursing homes, assisted living facilities, prisons, and certain high-density residential buildings.
If there is a person who has tested positive with COVID-19 at a skilled nursing facility, they can be retested at 3 days, 7 days, 10 days and 14 days after the initial test. This is to help prevent community-wide outbreaks.
*For all sites, regardless of whether a person has tested positive, testing is offered at intake, discharge, and for certain residents who require regular care outside of the facility.



Staff at correctional facilities


Any Vermonter without symptoms can be tested at a pop-up site without a doctorâs referral, but registration for testing is required. Regular test collection locations still require a doctorâs referral.

The following groups are encouraged to get tested at these sites: health care workers, first responders (EMS, fire, and law enforcement), child care providers currently serving essential workers, and anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

questionOriginal: Iâm a health professional and would like to volunteer. How do I get a temporary license?
questionText: Iâm a health professional and would like to volunteer. How do I get a temporary license?
answerOriginal:
Health care professionals can quickly become temporarily licensed to provide care during the COVID-19 public health emergency. This includes people who were previously licensed, even if they are retired from practice and do not hold an active license in any state.

The new emergency measures grant a temporary license for health professionals who:

  • Are licensed and in good standing in other states
  • Were licensed in Vermont, but whose licenses lapsed in recent years

There are no fees of any kind to obtain a temporary emergency license.

The process for applying will depend on the applicantâs status. Some just need to submit information about who they are and where they will be practicing. Others will be required to apply for the license using a streamlined process.

To apply for a license or get more information about the process contact the licensing authority for your profession:

  • Board of Medical Practice (medical doctors, physician assistants, and podiatrists) or 802-657-4223.
  • Office of Professional Regulation (other health care professions â including nurses and osteopathic physicians) or 802-828-1505.

questionOriginal: I have recovered from COVID-19. Can I donate my blood plasma to help other people suffering from COVID-19?
questionText: I have recovered from COVID-19. Can I donate my blood plasma to help other people suffering from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
People who have fully recovered from COVID-19 have antibodies in their blood plasma. This is the bodyâs immune response to the virus. Currently, plasma donations are only being done experimentally. It has not yet been confirmed by the scientific community. However, it could prove to be important in the future to treating serious cases of illness from COVID-19.

The Red Cross is looking for people who are fully recovered from COVID-19 and may be able to donate plasma. If you are fully recovered from a COVID-19 diagnosis that was confirmed by a lab test and would like to donate your plasma, fill out the form on the Red Cross website.

questionOriginal: Can I take ibuprofen for COVID-19 symptoms?
questionText: Can I take ibuprofen for COVID-19 symptoms?
answerOriginal:
Some early news reports suggested that non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen, could worsen coronavirus disease. However, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has said it is not aware of any scientific evidence connecting the use of NSAIDs with worsening COVID-19 symptoms at this time. The FDA is investigating this issue further.

There are multiple medicines you can buy with or without a doctorâs prescription that are approved for pain relief and fever reduction. Please read warning labels on all medications before using them and consult with your health care provider about what is best for you.

questionOriginal: Does smoking or vaping increase the risk of getting seriously ill from COVID-19?
questionText: Does smoking or vaping increase the risk of getting seriously ill from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
There is growing evidence that e-cigarette use or vaping can harm lung health. The coronavirus attacks the lungs, making it harder for people who smoke or vape â tobacco, cannabis or anything else â to fight off the virus, putting them at much greater risk of severe illness, even death.

802Quits is the Vermont tobacco quit resource. You can get help to quit by phone or online.

By phone, call 1-800-QUIT-NOW for 1:1 coaching, available 24/7, with email and text support.

Online: 802Quits.org

By quitting, youâll also protect people in your household by reducing their exposure to secondhand smoke and aerosol as you spend more time at home right now.

There is growing evidence that e-cigarette use or vaping can harm lung health. The coronavirus attacks the lungs, making it harder for people who smoke or vape â tobacco, cannabis or anything else â to fight off the virus, putting them at much greater risk of severe illness, even death.

questionOriginal: What is the difference between COVID-19 and the flu?
questionText: What is the difference between COVID-19 and the flu?
answerOriginal:
COVID-19 is a new disease and we are still learning about how it makes people sick.

Cause

COVID-19: Caused by one virus, the novel 2019 coronavirus, now called severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2, or SARS-CoV-2.

Flu: Caused by any of several different types and strains of influenza viruses.

Transmission

While both the flu and COVID-19 may be transmitted in similar ways, there is also a possible difference: COVID-19 might be spread through the airborne route, meaning that tiny droplets remaining in the air could cause disease in others even after the ill person is no longer near.

Antiviral Medications

COVID-19: Antiviral medications are currently being tested to see if they can address symptoms.

Flu: Antiviral medications can address symptoms and sometimes shorten the duration of the illness.

Vaccine

COVID-19: No vaccine is available at this time, though it is in progress.

Flu: A vaccine is available and effective to prevent some of the most dangerous types or to reduce the severity of the flu.

Find out more about deaths and infections from Johns Hopkins Medicine.

Flu: Caused by any of several different types and strains of influenza viruses.
Transmission
While both the flu and COVID-19 may be transmitted in similar ways, there is also a possible difference: COVID-19 might be spread through the airborne route, meaning that tiny droplets remaining in the air could cause disease in others even after the ill person is no longer near.
Antiviral Medications
COVID-19: Antiviral medications are currently being tested to see if they can address symptoms.
Flu: Antiviral medications can address symptoms and sometimes shorten the duration of the illness.
Vaccine
COVID-19: No vaccine is available at this time, though it is in progress.

questionOriginal: What should health care workers do?
questionText: What should health care workers do?
answerOriginal:
The Health Department now has a dedicated webpage for health care workers - healthvermont.gov/covid19-providers. It includes current guidance, health alerts, and resources for protecting patients and health care workers in different settings.

Report all suspected cases of COVID-19 immediately to the Vermont Department of Health Infectious Disease Epidemiology by calling 802-863-7240 (24/7).

If you suspect that a patient with a fever or respiratory illness has COVID-19:

  • Give the patient a surgical mask.

  • Notify facility infection control personnel immediately.

  • Use standard precautions, contact precautions, airborne precautions, and use eye protection when entering the room.

  • Evaluate the patient in a private room with the door closed, ideally in an airborne infection isolation room

questionOriginal: Can I get the virus from food?
questionText: Can I get the virus from food?
answerOriginal:
Unlike foodborne gastrointestinal (GI) viruses that often make people sick from contaminated food, COVID-19 is a virus that causes respiratory illness. The COVID-19 virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Currently, there is no evidence to show that COVID-19 is spread through food or food packaging.

It is important to always follow general food safety guidelines:

  • Wash your hands with soap and water for 20 seconds before preparing or eating food.

  • Throughout the day, wash your hands after blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing, or going to the bathroom.

It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object, like a package or container, that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

Find shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the FDA and tips on how to handle and prepare food safely from the CDC.

Learn from the CDC how to help prevent spread of the virus and how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.
answerText:
Unlike foodborne gastrointestinal (GI) viruses that often make people sick from contaminated food, COVID-19 is a virus that causes respiratory illness. The COVID-19 virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Currently, there is no evidence to show that COVID-19 is spread through food or food packaging.
It is important to always follow general food safety guidelines:


Wash your hands with soap and water for 20 seconds before preparing or eating food.


Throughout the day, wash your hands after blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing, or going to the bathroom.


It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object, like a package or container, that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.
Find shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the FDA and tips on how to handle and prepare food safely from the CDC.
Learn from the CDC how to help prevent spread of the virus and how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.

questionOriginal: How can I prepare at home?
questionText: How can I prepare at home?
answerOriginal:
• Plan ways to care for those in your home who might be at greater risk for serious complications, like older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have underlying medical conditions. Make sure those who need regular medicine, medical supplies and equipment have what they need.

  • Choose a room in your home that can be used to separate sick household members from those who are healthy. Identify a separate bathroom for the sick person to use, if possible. Plan to clean these rooms, as needed, when someone is sick.

  • Make sure you have enough groceries and other supplies for 14 days in case you get sick and need to quarantine. Stock up on only what you will need for 14 days. Do not buy more than you will need so you can leave supplies for other people.

  • Get support from others. Talk with your neighbors about emergency planning. If your neighborhood has Front Porch Forum, consider joining to connect with neighbors, information and resources. Stay in touch by phone or email with family and friends, especially those who are 65 years and older, who have underlying medical conditions, or who live alone.

  • Take care of the emotional health of your household members. Outbreaks can be stressful for adults and children. Talk with your children about the outbreak, try to stay calm, and reassure them that they are safe.

  • Keep a daily list of other people you are in close contact with. As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

Read Preventing COVID-19: Tips for Large Households or Extended Families Living in the Same Space.

questionOriginal: How long can the virus live on surfaces?
questionText: How long can the virus live on surfaces?
answerOriginal:
Current evidence suggests that the COVID-19 virus may live for hours to days on surfaces made from a variety of materials, according to the CDC. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or an object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes. However, this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.

Cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces daily are the best ways to help stop the spread of the COVID-19 virus in households and community settings.

Read the CDC's cleaning and disinfection for households guidance for more information.

questionOriginal: How do I wash or sanitize my hands to keep from getting sick?
questionText: How do I wash or sanitize my hands to keep from getting sick?
answerOriginal:
CDC recommends the following for hand hygiene: Household members should clean hands often, including immediately after removing gloves and after contact with someone who is ill, by washing hands with soap and water for 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available and hands are not visibly dirty, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. However, if hands are visibly dirty, always wash hands with soap and water.

Hand Sanitizer Recipe (based on recipe from the World Health Organization):

  • 1 cup (250 mL) isopropyl alcohol (91%)

  • 1 teaspoon (5 mL) glycerol (or other moisturizer such as aloe vera gel, warm honey or olive oil)

  • 2 Tablespoons (33 mL) water

Add the ingredients in the order listed above to a clean container, mixing with a spoon. If using honey, stir until the honey is completely dissolved. Keep this mixture out of the reach of children. The final concentration of isopropyl alcohol in this mixture is 75%, so keep it away from flames.

questionOriginal: What is contact tracing?
questionText: What is contact tracing?
answerOriginal:
Contact tracing is a strategy used to determine the source of an infection and how it is spreading. Finding people who are close contacts to a person who has tested positive for COVID-19, and therefore at higher risk of becoming infected themselves, can help prevent further spread of the virus.

A team of callers tries to reach anyone who has tested positive for COVID-19. They ask the patient questions about their activities within a certain timeframe â to help identify anyone they had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than six feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) Those contacts might include family members, co-workers or health care providers. Please note, the Health Department only uses a live person for contact tracing and never uses anything that sounds like a âroboâ (computer-generated voice) call.

The team then gets in touch with those contacts and provides health guidance on what to do if you are a close contact of someone who is diagnosed with COVID-19. A close contact is asked to stay home for 14 days and watch for symptoms.

While we have been successful in contact tracing, we will continue to add resources and personnel needed to address any increase in the number of people who test positive, which we expect to happen with more testing. This includes the use of technology to help in these efforts. We will be using an app called SARA Alert, a secure monitoring and reporting system for public health that is being used in other states. This system will allow us to offer people who have tested positive for COVID-19, and their close contacts, to enroll in a text-based system to help us keep in touch and monitor their symptoms.

As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What is the Health Department doing about long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities?
questionText: What is the Health Department doing about long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities?
answerOriginal:
The Heath Department is contacting all long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities proactively to review strategies to prevent COVID-19 infection and develop plans to respond immediately if an infection is identified. We complete an in-depth assessment by phone and provide guidance about personal protective equipment and other infection prevention and control recommendations. We continue to stay in touch for any technical assistance needs and additional questions.

If a case of COVID-19 is associated with a long-term care facility, an epidemiology team is quickly activated. They contact the facility to provide recommendations and infection control support. The team begins contact tracing to determine the source of the infection and how it may be spreading. They ask questions and collect information to help identify anyone the patient had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than 6 feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) The team communicates with close contacts to ensure isolation and quarantine guidelines are being followed, which will differ depending on the type of setting.

questionOriginal: What does close contact mean?
questionText: What does close contact mean?
answerOriginal:
Close contact means being within 6 feet, for a long time, of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 during their infectious period, which starts two days (48 hours) before any symptoms began and continues until they are recovered. Close contact does not mean being more than 6 feet away in the same indoor environment for a long period of time, walking by, or briefly being in the same room with someone.

A âlong period of timeâ is hard to define because it depends on whether the person was sick at the time and what type of interaction you had with that person. These examples can help you determine whether you were a close contact or not.

Examples of close contacts:

  • You live in the same home.

  • You are intimate partners.

  • You rode in the same car while the person was infectious.

  • You had dinner together while the person was infectious.

Examples of not close contacts:

  • You were their cashier at the grocery store.

  • You are a pharmacist who gave the person medication.

  • You were in front of the person in line at the store.

  • You are a coworker who briefly walked by to ask a question.

A team at the Health Department works with people with COVID-19 to identify their close contacts. This is called contact tracing. The team assesses each close contact for their exposure risk and gives them health guidance and recommendations for self-isolation or other restrictions.

As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

The chart describing what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation has details about what you should do and not do, depending on your exposure risk.

Find out more about what to do if you are a close contact of someone who is diagnosed with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What should I do if I need to see a dentist?
questionText: What should I do if I need to see a dentist?
answerOriginal:
Dentists can now perform all dental procedures again, including those that generate aerosol. The dental community is confident it has the necessary knowledge, skills, office processes and equipment, testing protocols, and personal protective equipment (PPE) to safely provide care.

Contact your dentist to find out if you can be seen. If you donât have a regular dentist and need help finding one, call 211.

Do not delay care if you have:

  • Heavy bleeding that wonât stop
  • Painful swelling in or around your mouth
  • Pain in a tooth, teeth or jawbone
  • Gum infection with pain or swelling
  • Treatment after surgery (dressing change, stitch removal)
  • Broken or knocked out tooth
  • Denture adjustment for people receiving radiation or other treatment for cancer
  • Wire of braces poking your cheek or gums
  • Biopsy of abnormal tissue

questionOriginal: Are campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts open?
questionText: Are campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts open?
answerOriginal:
Campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts are only open for limited in-person operations.

Find up-to-date guidance for campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD).

Businesses must follow mandatory health and safety requirements from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) that requires employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.

Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses.
answerText:
Lodging facilities â hotels, motels, bed and breakfasts, inns, short-term rentals (for example, VRBO, Homeaway, Airbnb, etc.), and all public and private camping facilities, RV parks, seasonal resorts and marinas â may accept overnight reservations from Vermont residents, those who have met the quarantine requirement, and essential workers.
Find details and up-to-date information on lodging, campgrounds and other accommodations from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD) ) and find information about traveling to Vermont from the Health Department.
All guests must complete a health questionnaire upon check-in and must provide a Vermont driverâs license or signed document certifying that they met the quarantine and travel requirements. Out-of-state guests are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert â a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for common symptoms of COVID-19 â for daily reminders from the Vermont Department of Health.
If an individual has concerns about lodging facilities that are violating the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order, the Department of Public Safety has created an online non-compliance complaint form to gather more information.

questionOriginal: Are bars and restaurants open?
questionText: Are bars and restaurants open?
answerOriginal:
On April 10, the Governor extended his order (effective Tuesday, March 17 at 2 p.m.) closing all bars and restaurants statewide until May 15.

Establishments can continue to offer food take out and delivery.

Find up-to-date guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements for bars, restaurants and food service from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD), which requires employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.

Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses.

The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.
answerText:
Restaurants may offer outdoor dining service under certain conditions. Bars, breweries, distilleries, cideries, and tasting rooms may also offer outdoor dining and beverage service under certain health and safety requirements.
Limited indoor dining at restaurants and bars is allowed.
Establishments can continue to offer food takeout and delivery.
Find more details and up-to-date information about bars, restaurants and food service from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

questionOriginal: What is known about Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) associated with COVID-19?
questionText: What is known about Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) associated with COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
According to the CDC, Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) is a condition where different body parts can become inflamed, including the heart, lungs, kidneys, brain, skin, eyes, or gastrointestinal organs. We do not yet know what causes MIS-C. However, we know that many children with MIS-C had the COVID-19 virus, or had been around someone with COVID-19. MIS-C can be serious, even deadly, but most children who were diagnosed with this condition have gotten better with medical care.

MIS-C is rare, and it remains unknown whether multisystem inflammatory syndrome only occurs in children or if it also can occur in adults.

Learn more about Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children and COVID-19 from the Vermont Department of Health.

questionOriginal: What should dentists know about COVID-19?
questionText: What should dentists know about COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
On April 27, a dental health care referral network for emergency dental procedures was set up. Read the April 27 Health Alert.

On April 10, Governor Phil Scott extended his order of dental health care professionals practicing in Vermont to suspend all elective dental care until May 15, 2020. This order applies to both children and adult patients. Read Addendum 9 to the Executive Order for more information.

Health care professionals must continue to be available to their patients as needed for emergencies and urgent care.

Read the March 23 Health Alert as it pertains to emergency and elective dental care in light of COVID-19, the rationale for this action, including definitions of what constitutes a dental emergency and conditions requiring urgent care.

Find more information for health care professionals.
answerText:
The challenge with dentistry is the generation of aerosols as part of many office-based activities. This includes dental hygiene through a variety of preventive, restorative, endodontic, periodontic and orthodontic procedures.
Dentists can now resume all procedures, including those that generate aerosol.Â Read the Interim Guidance for Resuming Dental Services in Vermont.
The dental community is confident it has the existing knowledge, skills, office processes and equipment, testing protocols, and personal protective equipment (PPE) to accomplish these safely. They will share the efforts and practices they have adopted with their patients.
Health care professionals must continue to be available to their patients as needed for emergencies and urgent care.
Find more information for health care professionals.

questionOriginal: Are outpatient services open?
questionText: Are outpatient services open?
answerOriginal:
Outpatient services are reopened for professions licensed by the Office of Professional Regulation.

Those professions that provide care without physical contact or with some physical contact Â may resume outpatient services â such as licensed alcohol and drug counselors (LADACs), Allied Mental Health, dieticians, psychologists, social workers, acupuncturists, chiropractors, physical therapists, occupational therapists, opticians and optometrists.

For those professions involved in care that is more likely to expose them to the COVID-19 virus â such as doctors of osteopathy, naturopathy, physician assistants, and nurses â outpatient clinic visits and diagnostic imaging may resume.

Outpatient services are reopened for professions licensed by the Office of Professional Regulation.
Those professions that provide care without physical contact or with some physical contact Â may resume outpatient services â such as licensed alcohol and drug counselors (LADACs), Allied Mental Health, dieticians, psychologists, social workers, acupuncturists, chiropractors, physical therapists, occupational therapists, opticians and optometrists.
For those professions involved in care that is more likely to expose them to the COVID-19 virus â such as doctors of osteopathy, naturopathy, physician assistants, and nurses â outpatient clinic visits and diagnostic imaging may resume.

questionOriginal: What do employers need to do to reopen their business?
questionText: What do employers need to do to reopen their business?
answerOriginal: All businesses must follow mandatory health and safety requirements as they reopen. Find up-to-date, sector-specific guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
answerText:
All businesses must follow mandatory health and safety requirements as they reopen.
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) has the resources businesses need on their COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses, including a step-by-step reopening guide for businesses and sector-specific guidance.
Stagnant water in plumbing systems can lead to illness or cause disease. As offices, retail businesses, gyms and other buildings begin to reopen, they should follow state guidance and recommendations before using the drinking water again. Read the CDCâs Guidance for Reopening Buildings After Prolonged Shutdown or Reduced Operation for more information.

questionOriginal: What information is available for long-term care facilities and other facilities that serve older Vermonters (group homes, nursing homes, assisted living, and state therapeutic care residences)?
questionText: What information is available for long-term care facilities and other facilities that serve older Vermonters (group homes, nursing homes, assisted living, and state therapeutic care residences)?
answerOriginal:
Starting June 19, facilities may offer limited visitation outside with residents. Check with the facility first before planning a visit.

Medically necessary personnel and visitors for residents receiving end-of-life care are allowed inside. Read the executive order.

The Health Department recommends that all health care personnel in long-term care facilities and other congregate settings where health care is provided wear face masks, regardless of the presence of COVID-19 in the facility.

Any new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine period first.

Senior Centers may reopen with guidance from the Health Department and the Department of Aging and Independent Living. Adult Day programs remain closed.

There is guidance Â­on preventing the spread of COVID-19 for managers and owners of senior living communities, which includes making a plan, preparing common spaces and communicating with residents/staff, in addition to outlining the role of the Health Department.

Find more guidance and information for long-term care and group living settings.

questionOriginal: Can pets get sick from COVID-19?
questionText: Can pets get sick from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
On April 5, the USDA confirmed the first case of a tiger being infected with COVID-19. The tiger is at a zoo in New York.

On April 22, the CDC announced the first confirmed cases of COVID-19 infection in two pet cats. These are the first pets in the U.S. to test positive. The cats live in two separate areas of New York State. Find out more from the CDCâs press release Confirmation of COVID-19 in Two Pet Cats in New York.

The CDC recommends the following:

  • Do not let pets interact with people or other animals outside the household.

  • Keep cats indoors when possible to prevent them from interacting with other animals or people.

  • Walk dogs on a leash, keeping at least 6 feet from other people and animals.

  • Avoid dog parks or public places where large numbers of people and dogs may gather.

At this time, routine testing of animals for COVID-19 is not recommended. Talk to your veterinarian about the best ways to care for your pet.

Learn more about what to do if you have animals from the CDC.

Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.
answerText:
We are still learning about the virus that causes COVID-19, but it appears that it can spread from people to animals in some situations.
There have been a few confirmed cases of animals infected with COVID-19:

a tiger at a zoo in New York
two pet cats in New York
a cat in Minnesota
aÂ dog in New York

The CDC recommends the following:
Until we learn more about how this virus affects animals, treat pets as you would other human family members to protect them from a possible infection.
Because there is a small risk that people with COVID-19 could spread the virus to animals, CDC recommends that pet owners limit their petâs interaction with people outside their household.

Keep cats indoors when possible and do not let them roam freely outside.
Walk dogs on a leash at least 6 feet away from others.
Avoid public places where large numbers of people gather.
Do not put face coverings on pets. Covering a petâs face could harm them.

Talk to your veterinarian if your pet gets sick or if you have any concerns about your petâs health.
Learn more about what to do if you have pets and answers to frequently asked questions about COVID-19 and animals from the CDC.
Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

questionOriginal: What do owners of lodging facilities need to do?
questionText: What do owners of lodging facilities need to do?
answerOriginal:
As of March 30, Governor Scott ordered all lodging facilities to close, except for exemptions when supporting the stateâs COVID-19 response. Lodging facilities include hotels, motels, bed and breakfasts, inns, short term rentals (for example, VRBO, Homeaway, Airbnb, etc.), and all public and private camping facilities and RV parks.

Governor Scott announced on April 10 that lodging operators may accept new reservations for stays and events occurring on June 15 or later. However, if the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order is extended, they will need to rebook.

All reservations between May 15 and May 22 need to be canceled. All reservations from out-of-state guests who cannot first meet the mandatory 14-day quarantine requirements must also be canceled through June 15. This date may be changed or extended.

Find up-to-date guidance for lodging and accommodations from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD).

Businesses must follow mandatory health and safety requirements that requires employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.

Read the COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses and find more resources for food and lodging businesses.

The Vermont State Police and local law enforcement will monitor lodging providers for compliance and work with the Attorney Generalâs Office on additional compliance measures if needed. Learn about guidance on enforcement of the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order from the Vermont Department of Public Safety.

The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.
answerText:
Lodging operations, short-term rentals, campgrounds and marinas may accept overnight reservations from Vermont residents, those who have met the quarantine requirement, and essential workers under mandatory health and safety requirements.
Lodging operators should recommend that all out-of-state guests sign up with Sara Alert once arriving in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. Guests from counties in New York and New England with low numbers of active infections do not need to quarantine. All other travelers coming to Vermont must quarantine. They have the option to quarantine at a lodging facility for 14 days if they make stops along the way or travel by plane, train, bus or other means of transportation.
Find details on the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses:

Up-to-date guidance for lodging and accommodations and for campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts. This includes having a health safety officer onsite at every shift and requiring employees to wear face coverings over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.
Answers to Be Smart, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses

Read the COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses and find more resources for food and lodging businesses from the Health Department.
The Vermont State Police and local law enforcement will monitor lodging providers for compliance and work with the Attorney Generalâs Office on additional compliance measures if needed. Learn about guidance on enforcement of the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order from the Vermont Department of Public Safety.
The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

questionOriginal: Are summer camps and residential summer college programs happening?
questionText: Are summer camps and residential summer college programs happening?
answerOriginal:
Summer day camps serving Vermonters and those meeting the 14-day quarantine requirements, overnight summer camps, and limited residential summer college programs may operate under the Health Guidance for Childcare Programs and Summer Programs.

Find information on the mandatory health and safety requirements for overnight camps and residential summer college programs, including quarantine requirements for out-of-state staff and campers, guidance for families dropping off campers, and wearing cloth face masks or coverings around other people, from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

Find more information about what parents can expect from child care and school age camps and care from the Vermont Department of Health.
answerText:

questionOriginal: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
questionText: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
People with COVID-19 have had a wide range of symptoms reported â ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness. These symptoms may appear 2 to 14 days after exposure to the virus:

  • Fever

  • Cough

  • Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing

  • Chills

  • Repeated shaking with chills

  • Muscle pain

  • Sore throat

  • New loss of taste or smell

You can check your symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.

Call your health care professional if you develop symptoms and ask if a test can be considered. Learn more about COVID-19.
answerText:
People with COVID-19 have had a wide range of symptoms reported â ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness. Symptoms may appear 2 to 14 days after exposure to the virus. Not everyone infected with the COVID-19 virus has symptoms. People with these symptoms may have COVID-19:

Fever (100.4 Â°F or greater) or chills
Cough
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Fatigue
Muscle or body aches
Headache
New loss of taste or smell
Sore throat
Congestion or runny nose
Nausea or vomiting
Diarrhea

This list does not include all possible symptoms. The CDC will continue to update the list of symptoms as more is learned. You can check your symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.
Call your health care provider if you are having symptoms. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic.
Learn more about COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Can I get tested with a swab in the front of my nose?
questionText: Can I get tested with a swab in the front of my nose?
answerOriginal:
There is a test available that uses a dry swab to collect a sample from the front of your nose. At this time, the supplies needed for this type of test are limited. This type of test is being prioritized for different groups of people who may not be able to tolerate the longer nose swab (nasopharyngeal or NP) that collects samples from the back of the nose and throat. This includes children, patients at risk of increased bleeding or complications, patients with nasal irregularities (for example, polyps, deviated septum), people who need regular and repeated testing (for example, employees or residents of skilled nursing facilities), and those without the cognitive ability to understand the testing procedure.

Your health care provider will determine if you should be referred for this type of test. Please note the pop-up testing sites use the longer NP swabs.

questionOriginal: Where can I buy cloth face masks or coverings?
questionText: Where can I buy cloth face masks or coverings?
answerOriginal:
The Department of Public Safety has put together a list of businesses with available cloth face masks or coverings. Please check the list of where to buy cloth face coverings. Many Vermonters can also use homemade cloth face masks or coverings to offer some protection to others.

You can also reach out to your community. Check out places like Front Porch Forum to connect with other Vermonters making cloth face masks or coverings.
answerText:
The Department of Public Safety has a list of where to buy face coverings from businesses.
You can also reach out to your community. Check out places like Front Porch Forum to connect with other Vermonters making cloth face masks or coverings.

questionOriginal: Can I use reusable grocery bags?
questionText: Can I use reusable grocery bags?
answerOriginal:
Yes, people can continue to use reusable grocery bags. However, some stores are choosing to no longer allow reusable bags and containers at this time. Check with your local store for their current policies.

Current evidence suggests that the COVID-19 virus may live for hours to days on surfaces made from a variety of materials. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

It is important to remember to wash your hands before you eat and avoid touching your face. Washing or wiping down your reusable bags with a disinfectant continues to be a best practice for preventing bacterial illnesses, such as E.coli, from meat and unwashed fruits and vegetables.
answerText:
Yes, people can continue to use reusable grocery bags. However, some stores are choosing to no longer allow reusable bags and containers at this time. Check with your local store for their current policies.
After July 1, stores and food service establishments will no longer provide plastic bags at check-out. Youâll have the option to purchase paper bags for 10 cents each or use reusable bags. If a store has temporarily banned reusable bags, consider putting your groceries back into your cart and bag them at your car. Some stores and food establishments may still offer plastic bags after July 1 since they are allowed to use the ones they currently have in stock until they are gone.
Current evidence suggests that the COVID-19 virus may live for hours to days on surfaces made from a variety of materials. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads. It is important to remember to wash your hands before you eat and to avoid touching your face.
Make sure you clean your reusable bags regularly, which can also help prevent illnesses from bacteria, such as E.coli, that are from meat and unwashed fruits and vegetables.
Find more information and tips about the single-use plastics ban from the Department of Environmental Conservation.

questionOriginal: Can I get COVID-19 from swimming in a lake or river?
questionText: Can I get COVID-19 from swimming in a lake or river?
answerOriginal:
The COVID-19 virus could possibly enter waterways through untreated wastewater that is discharged into waterways following large rain events or for other reasons. The virus has been found in untreated wastewater, but there has been no evidence that a person can get COVID-19 from being exposed to untreated wastewater or sewerage systems.

According to the CDC, it is thought that the COVID-19 virus does not spread through standard municipal and individual septic system wastewater treatment practices. Guidance will be updated if anything new is learned.

The Health Department recommends that towns do routine weekly E. coli testing and after large storm events during the swim season. These tests are a good indication of the water quality, meaning that if the E. coli levels are low, then COVID-19 virus levels are also expected to be low.

The best practices for staying healthy while swimming are to obey signage at beaches, do not swim during and following large rain events, and do not swallow the water.
