questionOriginal: What is monitoring?
questionText: What is monitoring?
answerOriginal:
Monitoring means someone who has returned from an affected area or cruise ship and does not have symptoms of COVID-19. They are advised by the Health Department to check their temperature every day, watch for symptoms, and quarantine for 14 days. Information that may identify someone under monitoring is not available to the public.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

The Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard includes the number of people being monitored and who have completed monitoring and is updated every day.
answerText:
Monitoring means someone who has returned from an affected area or cruise ship and does not have symptoms of COVID-19 or someone who signed up with Sara Alert for daily symptom check reminders. Information that may identify someone under monitoring is not available to the public.
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested. Find out how under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
The Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard includes the number of people being monitored and the number of people who have completed monitoring and is updated every day.

questionOriginal: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
questionText: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
answerOriginal:
Anyone currently under quarantine who is not a health care worker or a correctional worker, and who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required.

This includes:

  • people returning to Vermont (for example, those who spend winter outside of Vermont, second homeowners and college students)

  • visitors coming into Vermont

  • close contacts of people who have tested positive

For anyone coming into Vermont, Day 0 is the day you arrive in Vermont.

Health care workers and correctional workers must complete the full 14-day quarantine.

You can end your quarantine period only if:

  • You have not had symptoms during your quarantine period.

  • You are tested on Day 7 or later.

  • You remain in quarantine until the result comes back.

  • You receive a negative test result and are still not having symptoms.

However, you must continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days and isolate at home immediately if symptoms develop.
answerText:
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested. Talk to your health care provider to find out where to get tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1.Â For travelers who are completing quarantine in their home state, your home state may offer testing for people without symptoms.
You can end your quarantine period before 14 days only if:

You have not had symptoms during your quarantine period;
You are tested on Day 7 or later;
You remain in quarantine until the result comes back; AND
You receive a negative test result and are still not having symptoms.

For anyone coming into Vermont, Day 1 is the day after you arrive in Vermont.
However, if you end your quarantine period before 14 days, you must continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days. If you develop symptoms at any point during your quarantine, contact your health care provider and the Health Department right away. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1. Sign up to receive daily symptom check reminders.
For close contacts of people who have tested positive:

If you are NOT able to completely physically separate yourself from the person who tested positive â for example, you live in the same home â Day 1 of your quarantine is the day after they have ended their self-isolation.
If you are able to completely physically separate from the person who tested positive â for example you do not live in the same home â Day 1 of your quarantine is the day after the last time you were in close contact with them.

Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by Day 7. This why there is the option for people to be tested at Day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine.
New admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine.

questionOriginal: What if Iâve had contact with someone who is under monitoring?
questionText: What if Iâve had contact with someone who is under monitoring?
answerOriginal:
There is no identifiable increased risk to someone who has been in a home or in close contact with a person who is under monitoring and is NOT sick (experiencing symptoms).

People are thought to be most contagious when they are most symptomatic (the sickest). It might be possible to spread the virus before people show symptoms â there have been reports of this happening â but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.
answerText: If you have been in a home or in close contact with a person who is under monitoring, you do not need to take any additional steps â as long as you are not experiencing COVID-19 symptoms.

questionOriginal: What does the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order mean for Vermonters?
questionText: What does the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order mean for Vermonters?
answerOriginal:
Vermonters may now leave home to get fresh air, begin limited social interactions and gatherings of 10 or fewer preferably in outdoor settings, provided that we follow health and safety precautions to keep disease from spreading. This means:

  • Keeping a physical distance of at least 6 feet away from others (except for those you live with).

  • Washing or sanitizing your hands often.

  • Wearing a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain (for example, at a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path).

  • Staying home and away from others if you are sick with COVID-19, have recently been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, or just donât feel well.

Learn how to safely connect with friends and family. These recommended practices will help you weigh the risk and plan accordingly.

Read the latest updates to the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order.

The Agency of Commerce and Community Development has resources for individuals and sector-specific guidance for details on which businesses are open.
answerText:
Under the Governorâs executive order extension â Be Smart, Stay Safe â Vermonters are encouraged to limit their exposure to the COVID-19 virus outside their homes as much as possible.
Vermonters should travel only as needed:

For personal safety, medical care and care of others
For work, although all workers should continue to work remotely whenever possible
For shopping and services available at all businesses and non-profit and government entities determined to be critical and those which have been authorized to resume operations
To get fresh air and exercise by taking advantage of outdoor recreation and outdoor fitness activities that require low or no direct physical contact
For limited social interactions and gatherings of 25 or fewer, preferably in outdoor settings
For in-state stays at available lodging, campground and marina facilities

Vermonters should follow health and safety precautions to help keep the virus from spreading by:

Staying home and away from others if you are sick with COVID-19, have recently been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, or just donât feel well.
Keeping a physical distance of at least 6 feet away from others (except for those you live with).
Washing or sanitizing your hands often.
Wearing a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain (for example, at a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path).
Coughing and sneezing into your elbow (even when wearing a face covering).
Limiting travel to within Vermont to the extent possible and when you do travel, limit non-essential stops.

Older adults (age 65 and over), and people with underlying medical conditions, like heart and lung disease or diabetes, are more likely to develop severe illness. They should take extra precautions.
Learn how to safely connect with friends and family. These recommended practices will help you weigh the risk and plan accordingly.
Read the latest updates to the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development has resources for individuals and sector-specific guidance for details on which businesses are open.

questionOriginal: Can we still have our wedding ceremony?
questionText: Can we still have our wedding ceremony?
answerOriginal:
At this time, marriage ceremonies are discouraged, and officiants must ask to postpone services. But if a ceremony is held, it must be in accordance with the governorâs orders. This includes limiting gatherings to fewer than 10 people in the same space at the same time.

Visitors from other states and countries are asked not to come to Vermont at this time. If they do come to Vermont, they must stay at home (quarantine) 14 days before participating in any activities out of their home or lodging.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Learn more about quarantine on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.

However, there are some exceptions, and this guidance may change. Find up-to-date information on marriage ceremonies from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.
answerText:
Justices of the peace and other officiants may perform in-person marriages if there are 25 or fewer people. Town offices may decide to issue marriage licenses.
Ceremonies should preferably be outside, while keeping a 6-foot distance from others, and wearing cloth face masks or coverings.
If you are visiting Vermont you may need to quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.
Find up-to-date information on marriage ceremonies from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development

questionOriginal: What can I wear if my health or work environment doesn't allow me to wear a cloth face mask or covering?
questionText: What can I wear if my health or work environment doesn't allow me to wear a cloth face mask or covering?
answerOriginal:
People who have trouble breathing can wear a light-weight bandanna or cloth covering tied to be open at the bottom or a face shield. Face shields are generally not recommended because they are more for health care settings to protect the person wearing it from droplets getting into their eyes. Face masks or coverings, like a cloth face mask or bandanna, do a better job than face shields of keeping droplets in. However, if your work environment or health does not allow you to wear a cloth face mask, wearing a face shield is better than having no barrier on your nose and mouth.

Outdoor workers who are doing strenuous work that causes heavy breathing are not required to wear a cloth face mask or covering when it is hot outside. Workers should keep masks with them and wear them when they are not exerting themselves (for example talking, resting, or interacting with other co-workers or people). It is important that workers keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible, especially when they are not wearing a mask.

It is important that workers keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible, especially when they are not wearing a mask.

questionOriginal: What is Sara Alert?
questionText: What is Sara Alert?
answerOriginal:
Sara Alert is a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for common symptoms of COVID-19. People who have tested positive for COVID-19, their close contacts, and people traveling or returning to Vermont can quickly and easily sign up for to receive free daily reminders to check themselves for symptoms by email, text or phone call. If symptoms are reported, the Health Department will reach out to provide guidance and next steps. Sara Alert helps our public health teams contain the spread of COVID-19.

Please note, Sara Alert is not a contact tracing system. It is not GPS based, so it does not monitor your movements.

If you are traveling or returning to Vermont, you are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.

Sign up for Sara Alert.

questionOriginal: What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
questionText: What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
answerOriginal:
• Isolation is for people who are sick with COVID-19.

  • Quarantine is for people with no symptoms and who were in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19 or are returning to Vermont from out of state for anything other than an essential purpose.

  • Self-observation is for other Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19.

For more information, see the What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation? chart.
answerText:
Isolation is for people who are sick with COVID-19.
Quarantine is for people with no symptoms who are returning to Vermont from out of state or who were in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19. This helps prevent spread of disease before a person knows they are sick or if they are infected with the virus without feeling symptoms.
Quarantine means staying at a home or dwelling for 14 days before doing any activities outside of the home, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. People in quarantine should separate themselves from others and check themselves for symptoms. Sign up for daily symptom check reminders.
Self-observation is for other Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19.
Find more information on the What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation? chart.
Check the latest quarantine guidance for people visiting or returning to Vermont.

questionOriginal: Do I need to quarantine if out-of-state visitors are staying in my home?
questionText: Do I need to quarantine if out-of-state visitors are staying in my home?
answerOriginal:
If you are hosting travelers under quarantine in your home or lodging, you do not also need to quarantine. If you are sharing space, stay at least 6 feet from the people under quarantine. People under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces. Disinfect commonly touched surfaces and check for symptoms for 14 days.

Visitors from counties in New York and New England with low numbers of active infections do not need to quarantine. Read the travel guidance and check the map of approved counties, which is updated weekly.

Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for information for travelers to Vermont. They can get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.
answerText:
If you are hosting travelers under quarantine in your home or lodging, you do not also need to quarantine. If you are sharing space, stay at least 6 feet from the people under quarantine. People under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces. Disinfect commonly touched surfaces and check for symptoms for 14 days.

They can get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

questionOriginal: Iâm young. Can I continue to socialize?
questionText: Iâm young. Can I continue to socialize?
answerOriginal:
Whatever your age, staying home is still the best way to lower our risk of COVID-19, but many of us are eager to take small steps to safely see our friends and family again. Small groups of 10 or fewer people are now allowed if health and safety precautions are followed. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

While older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions are at greatest risk, young people are not immune to getting sick. Even people who show only mild symptoms may pass the virus to others â particularly in the early course of the infection, before they even realize they are sick. Taking health and safety precautions protects everyone and helps slow the spread of this virus.
answerText:
Whatever your age, staying home is still the best way to lower our risk of COVID-19, but many of us are eager to take small steps to safely see our friends and family again. Groups of 25 or fewer people are allowed to gather if health and safety precautions are followed. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
Even though the risk for severe illness increases with age and is higher for older adults and people of any age with certain underlying medical conditions, young people can also get sick. The virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms. Taking health and safety precautions protects everyone and helps slow the spread of this virus. Everyone should wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

questionOriginal: Can the COVID-19 virus spread through pools and hot tubs?
questionText: Can the COVID-19 virus spread through pools and hot tubs?
answerOriginal:
There is no evidence that COVID-19 can be spread to humans through the use of pools and hot tubs. Proper operation, maintenance, and disinfection (for example, with chlorine and bromine) of pools and hot tubs should remove or inactivate the virus that causes COVID-19.

Find more information from the CDC's Water and COVID-19 FAQs.
answerText:
There is no evidence that the virus can spread to people through the use of pools, hot tubs or water playgrounds. Proper operation and disinfection of the water (for example, with chlorine and bromine) should kill the virus.
Everyone should follow these general precautions to help prevent the COVID-19 virus from spreading: wear a cloth face mask or covering when youâre not in the water, keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.
Find more more frequently asked questions about COVID-19 and water from the CDC.

questionOriginal: How can I safely run errands for essential purposes?
questionText: How can I safely run errands for essential purposes?
answerOriginal: The CDC has guidance on how to meet basic household needs, such as going grocery shopping, picking up medicine, picking up take-out, banking, getting gas, and going to doctor visits. Read the CDCâs Running Essential Errands guidance.
answerText: The CDC has guidance on how to safely run essential errands to meet basic household needs, such as going grocery shopping, getting deliveries and take-out, banking, and getting gas.

questionOriginal: Are mass gatherings (ceremonies, events, fairs or festivals) allowed?
questionText: Are mass gatherings (ceremonies, events, fairs or festivals) allowed?
answerOriginal:
Vermonters are allowed to gather in groups of 25 or fewer people as long as health and safety precautions are followed. Choose other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

Vermonters may hold yard sales and garage sales with 25 or fewer people. Hosts and visitors must keep a distance of at least 6 feet from others, and it is recommended that they wear cloth face masks or coverings.

Gatherings of more than 25 people are still prohibited. This includes weddings, graduation ceremonies, and other social gatherings.

All traditional fairs and festivals have been canceled until further notice.

Organized outdoor markets, like flea markets, must follow the farmers market guidance from the Agency of Agriculture, Food & Markets (AAFM).

Farmers markets and pick-your-own farms and orchards must follow best practices outlined by AAFM.

Starting June 26, event venues, arts, culture and entertainment venues, and restaurants can hold events, such as weddings, funerals and parties, with certain occupancy limits and health and safety precautions. Outdoor services, events, and gatherings are strongly preferred.

Find more information on the health and safety requirements for sectors that are open from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

At any gathering or event, everyone should follow these general precautions:Â wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep aÂ 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.
answerText:
Event venues, arts, culture and entertainment venues, and restaurants can hold events, such as weddings, funerals and parties, with certain occupancy limits and health and safety precautions. Outdoor services, events, and gatherings are strongly preferred.
All traditional fairs and festivals have been canceled until further notice.
Organized outdoor markets, like flea markets, must follow the farmers market guidance from the Agency of Agriculture, Food & Markets (AAFM).
Farmers markets and pick-your-own farms and orchards must follow best practices outlined by AAFM.
Libraries, galleries, museums, theaters and other indoor arts, culture and entertainment organizations are open with certain occupancy limits and health and safety precautions.
Find more information on the health and safety requirements for sectors that are open from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
At any gathering or event, everyone should follow these general precautions: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.

questionOriginal: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
questionText: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to find out if you should be tested.

Follow these guidelines to help keep others from getting sick:

Isolate at home:

  • Donât leave home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting a health care provider or emergency department. Wear a cloth face mask or covering if you need to leave home for medical care

  • Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.

  • Stay in a specific room in your home and use a separate bathroom, as much as possible. Stay at least 6 feet away from others in your home at all times and wear a cloth face mask or covering if you are in the same room with them. Donât share household items.

  • Have someone else care for your pets. There have been a small number of pets, including cats and dogs, reported to be infected with the COVID-19 virus, mostly after close contact with people with COVID-19. If you must care for your pet, wear a cloth face mask or covering, and wash your hands before and after.

Daily cleaning and washing:

  • Clean and disinfect surfaces in your separate room and bathroom. Have someone else clean the other areas of your home.

  • Thoroughly wash household items, like utensils, after using.

  • Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water arenât available.

Find out what to do if you are diagnosed with COVID-19.

For more information, see CDC's guidance on what to do if you are sick.
answerText:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to find out if you should be tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic.
Follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and community:

Stay home except to get medical care.
Separate yourself from other people.
Monitor your symptoms.
Call ahead before visiting your doctor.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering when youâre around people and pets.
Cover your coughs and sneezes.
Wash your hands often.
Avoid sharing personal household items.
Clean all high-touch surfaces daily.

Find more details on what to do if you are sick from the CDC.

questionOriginal: Is it safe to go grocery shopping?
questionText: Is it safe to go grocery shopping?
answerOriginal:
Currently there is no evidence to show that the COVID-19 virus is spread through food or food packaging. However, there is concern about being able to keep at least 6 feet away from other shoppers and to reduce your risk of getting sick while getting groceries.

The Vermont Retail & Grocers Association has a regularly updated list of what services Vermont retailers and grocers are offering during the COVID-19 pandemic. These services range from limited delivery, to curbside pickup and designated shopping hours for vulnerable populations.

Anyone who is sick or thinks they might be sick should stay home. Ask a family member, friend or neighbor to help you get your groceries, or see about having food delivered.

When you leave the store, you should wash your hands or use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Read more about shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the Food and Drug Administration.
answerText:
Currently there is no evidence to show that the COVID-19 virus is spread through food or food packaging. Follow these tips to stay safe while you shop:

Stay home if you are sick. Ask a family member, friend or neighbor to help you get your groceries, or see about having food delivered.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering while youâre in the store.
Keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible. Follow any arrows on the floor or other signage that directs how people should move through the store.
When you leave the store, wash your hands or use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.

The Vermont Retail & Grocers Association has a regularly updated list of what services Vermont retailers and grocers are offering during the COVID-19 pandemic. These services range from limited delivery, to curbside pickup and designated shopping hours for vulnerable populations.
Read more about shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the Food and Drug Administration.

questionOriginal: What should returning and new college students do?
questionText: What should returning and new college students do?
answerOriginal:
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

All students are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert once arriving in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.

Students from counties in New York and New England with low numbers of active infections do not need to quarantine. Read the travel guidance and check the map of approved counties, which is updated weekly.

College students returning to Burlington can also use the cityâs Supportive Quarantine Pilot Program. The program includes a move-in care package of fresh local goods, a mask, and hygiene supplies.

Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.
Students from certain approved counties with low rates of active cases do not need to quarantine.
All students are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert once arriving in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.
College students returning to Burlington can also use the cityâs Supportive Quarantine Pilot Program. The program includes a move-in care package of fresh local goods, a mask, and hygiene supplies.

questionOriginal: Are there any recommendations for older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions?
questionText: Are there any recommendations for older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions?
answerOriginal:
According to the CDC, some people might be at higher risk of getting very sick from COVID-19, including older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have serious underlying medical conditions like heart disease, diabetes, lung disease or moderate to severe asthma, severe obesity, chronic kidney disease undergoing dialysis, liver disease, or people who are immunocompromised including cancer treatment. People who live in a nursing home or long-term care facility are also at high risk of getting very sick from COVID-19.

In addition to the general COVID-19 prevention steps, older adults and people with underlying medical conditions should take extra precautions including:

  • Continue your medications and do not change your treatment plan without talking to your health care provider.

  • Stay home as much as possible, leaving only for essential purposes, like going to the grocery store and pharmacy. Consider having groceries or medications delivered.

  • Have at least a 2-week supply of prescription and non-prescription medications.

  • Talk to your health care provider about whether your vaccinations are up to date.

  • Do not delay getting emergency care for your underlying medical condition because of COVID-19.

  • Call your health care provider if you have any concerns about your underlying medical conditions or if you get sick and think that you may have COVID-19.

Read the CDCâs full guidance on people who are at higher risk for serious illness from COVID-19.
answerText:
According to the CDC, risk for severe illness from COVID-19 increases with age, with older adults at highest risk. People of any age with certain underlying medical conditions are also at increased risk for severe illness. In addition to the general COVID-19 prevention steps, these groups should consider limiting their risk:

Stay close to home as much as possible. Traveling out of state is not recommended since the virus is still widespread in neighboring states and across the country.
Be aware of your surroundings. Choose outdoor settings over indoor settings. Pay attention to the size of the space, crowding, the number of people there, and if they are wearing face coverings and keeping a 6-foot distance.
Choose activities that donât require close contact. Minimize close contact while talking or doing anything that requires exertion, shouting or singing.
Keep your social circle small. Choose a few other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions.

The CDC recommends other populations also take extra precautions, like pregnant people, people experiencing homelessness, and people with disabilities.

questionOriginal: Do I need to quarantine if I do a short trip (day trip)?
questionText: Do I need to quarantine if I do a short trip (day trip)?
answerOriginal: People who regularly commute to or from Vermont do not need to quarantine.Â In addition, people who live near a border and regularly travel to and from a neighboring state may make day trips to that state for essential work, health care, and other essential needs like groceries or visitation for parental shared custody without quarantining. For anyone else making a day trip to or from Vermont, read the cross-state travel guidance from theÂ Agency of Commerce and Community Development.
answerText:
People who live near the Vermont border and regularly travel to and from a neighboring state may make day trips to VermontÂ for work, health care, and other essential needs like groceries or visitation for parental shared custody without quarantining.
If you go on a day trip that is not in an approved county with low rates of active cases, you must quarantine in Vermont upon return.

questionOriginal: How can I help protect myself from getting the virus?
questionText: How can I help protect myself from getting the virus?
answerOriginal:
The best way to prevent yourself and others from getting sick with COVID-19 is to avoid being exposed to the virus. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Everyone should:

  • Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after being in a public place, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.

  • If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Cover all surfaces of your hands and rub them together until they feel dry.

  • Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.

  • Stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.

  • Avoid close contact with people who are sick.

  • Wear a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, at a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.

  • Stay home when you are sick.

  • Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or the inside of your elbow. Throw used tissues in the trash. Then immediately wash your hands with soap and water or use an alcohol-based sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.

  • Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily.

Learn more about COVID-19 prevention and how to protect yourself and others.
answerText:
The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Here is how you can protect yourself from COVID-19, and avoid spreading it to others:

Stay at home to protect others if you are sick.
Keep gatherings small and have them outside whenever possible.
When you leave home, stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when you cannot keep a 6-foot distance from other people, for example, at a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path. Masks may be required in some places like on public transportation.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or the inside of your elbow. Throw used tissues in the trash. Then immediately wash your hands with soap and water or use an alcohol-based sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after being in a public place, going to the bathroom, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.
If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Always wash hands with soap and water if your hands look dirty.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces (like tables, hard-backed chairs, doorknobs, light switches, remote controllers, handles, desks, toilets, sinks) using a regular household cleaning spray or wipe
Travel increases your chances of getting and spreading COVID-19. Check the guidance for people traveling to Vermont, and read CDC's guidance on travel in the United States.

Learn more about COVID-19 prevention and how to protect yourself and others.

questionOriginal: What does social distancing mean?
questionText: What does social distancing mean?
answerOriginal:
Social distancing means maintaining a physical distance (approximately 6 feet or 2 meters) from others you do not live with. This includes when you're inside a store or outside for exercise.

The COVID-19 virus spreads easily from person-to-person. It travels through the air when a sick person coughs, sneezes or talks. One way to contain the spread of COVID-19 is to stop people from sharing it. Without a vaccine or treatment, we can help contain the virus by:

  • Staying at home to protect others if you are sick.

  • Staying home is still the best way to lower our risk of COVID-19, but small groups of 10 or fewer people are now allowed if health and safety precautions are followed. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

  • Continuing to go outside, take walks, do essential errands while maintaining a physical distance from others and practicing proper hygiene. Remember that ticks are active this time of year. Find out how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites.

  • Wearing a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain, especially at the grocery store, pharmacy, doctorâs office, hospital or other essential business or office, and on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.

  • Washing your hands (adults and children) any time you go inside, before you eat, and before you spend time with people who are more vulnerable to the effects of COVID-19.
answerText:
Social distancing means maintaining a physical distance (approximately 6 feet or 2 meters) from people you do not live with. This includes when youâre inside a store, gathering with friends or family, or outside for exercise or a walk.
The COVID-19 virus spreads easily from person-to-person. It travels through the air from respiratory droplets released when an infected person coughs, sneezes or talks. A person can be infected and not have any symptoms. In addition to keeping a 6-foot distance from others, everyone should:

Stay home to protect others if you are sick.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when you cannot keep a 6-foot distance from other people, for example, at the grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after being in a public place, going to the bathroom, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.
Keep groups small when you can to limit any possible exposure, and follow health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

questionOriginal: What should pregnant or breastfeeding people do?
questionText: What should pregnant or breastfeeding people do?
answerOriginal:
We do not currently know if pregnant people have a greater chance of getting sick from COVID-19 than the general public nor whether they are more likely to have serious illness as a result. Based on available information, pregnant people seem to have the same risk as adults who are not pregnant.

Learn more from CDC about COVID-19 and pregnancy and breastfeeding.

Find more resources for families with children.
answerText:
Based on what we know at this time,Â pregnant peopleÂ might be at an increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19Â compared to non-pregnant people. Additionally, there may be an increased risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes, such as preterm birth, among pregnant people with COVID-19. Therefore, if you are pregnant, be mindful about reducing your risk of getting sick.
Learn more from CDC about COVID-19 and pregnancy and breastfeeding.
Find more resources for families with children.

questionOriginal: What is serologic, or antibody, testing and will it be used in Vermont?
questionText: What is serologic, or antibody, testing and will it be used in Vermont?
answerOriginal:
Serologic testing measures antibodies in the blood of a person who has been infected with COVID-19, whether they felt sick or not. In other words, it measures the bodyâs immune response to the virus, but does not detect the virus itself. According to the FDA, in the early days of an infection when the bodyâs immune response is still building, antibodies may not be detected. This limits the testâs effectiveness for diagnosing COVID-19 and why it should not be used as the sole basis to diagnose COVID-19.

With any test, there is always a risk of incorrect test results â false positive and false negative results. We need a good and accurate test we can rely on. The Vermont Department of Health convened a working group of experts to research antibody tests. Their findings conclude that at this time, the serologic (antibody) tests that are currently available are not accurate or reliable enough. Based on these findings, they caution against using serologic testing to make decisions about individuals. For example, using this test to establish âproof of immunity.â However, this type of test could help us better understand the population-level rate of infection from COVID-19 in Vermont.

We will continue to use public health best practice â considering clinical data, exposure history, and what is happening at the community-level â to make decisions on when to reopen businesses and when to return to work. The working group will continue to meet regularly and will be watching closely for changes and improvements in serologic testing. Recommendations may change based on new data.
answerText:
Serologic testing measures antibodies in the blood of a person who has been infected with COVID-19, whether they felt sick or not. In other words, it measures the bodyâs immune response to the virus, but does not detect the virus itself.
With any test, there is always a risk of incorrect test results â false positive and false negative results. We need a good and accurate test we can rely on. The Vermont Department of Health convened a working group of experts to research antibody tests. Their findings conclude that at this time, the serologic (antibody) tests that are currently available would not produce results that are accurate or reliable enough in Vermont. The working group will continue to meet regularly and will be watching closely for changes and improvements in serologic testing. Recommendations may change based on new data.
Though certain providers may offer antibody testing in Vermont, the working group cautions against using serologic testing to make decisions about individuals, for example, using this test to establish âproof of immunity.â However, this type of test could help us better understand the population-level rate of infection from COVID-19 in Vermont.

questionOriginal: Does the Health Department have enough resources for testing?
questionText: Does the Health Department have enough resources for testing?
answerOriginal: Testing capacity in Vermont and in the U.S. has improved since mid-March. We have worked continuously to grow our stock of in-state supplies and to build relationships with private labs to help speed up processing of tests. Testing is done seven days a week with typically 1- to 3-day turnaround times. In addition to the Health Departmentâs lab, the University of Vermont Medical Centerâs lab and commercial labs are doing COVID-19 testing.
answerText: Testing capacity in Vermont and in the U.S. has improved since mid-March. We have worked continuously to grow our stock of in-state supplies and to build relationships with private labs to help speed up processing of tests. In addition to the Health Departmentâs lab, the University of Vermont Medical Centerâs lab and commercial labs are doing COVID-19 testing.

questionOriginal: How is a sample collected for COVID-19 testing?
questionText: How is a sample collected for COVID-19 testing?
answerOriginal:
Usually a health care provider collects samples (specimens) from you in one of two ways, but there are other options:

  1. The health care provider collects a nasal, or nasopharyngeal (NP) swab. This is when a dry swab is inserted through one nostril and is rubbed against the back of your nose and throat.
  2. The health care provider collects a sample from the front of your nose with a dry swab.

questionOriginal: Can I get together with friends and family?
questionText: Can I get together with friends and family?
answerOriginal:
On May 6, the Governor announced Play Smart and Play Safe: Restart VT Phase 5, which gives Vermonters a chance to reunite and enjoy each otherâs company. This allows Vermonters to leave home to get fresh air and exercise and to resume limited social interactions and gatherings of 10 or fewer people, preferably in outdoor settings, as long as health and safety precautions are taken. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

Members of one household may choose to socialize â and allow children to play â with members of another trusted household, such as family, neighbors or friends. A trusted household is one that has taken seriously the importance of social distancing and proper hygiene in their day-to-day lives. By carefully limiting these closer social interactions at this time it will be easier to identify who else may have been exposed and need to self-isolate in case someone becomes sick.

To keep COVID-19 from spreading, we must continue to:

  • Stay home and away from others if you are sick with COVID-19, have recently been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, or just donât feel well.

  • Keep a 6-foot distance from others when you meet people outside of your household.

  • Wash your hands frequently (hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol is acceptable when soap and water are not available).

  • Cough and sneeze into your elbow (even if you are wearing a cloth face mask or covering).

  • Wear a cloth face mask or covering over your nose and mouth.

Older adults (age 65 and over), and people with underlying medical conditions, like heart and lung disease or diabetes, are more likely to develop severe illness. They should continue to stay home, and family and friends should do everything they can to help keep them safe.
answerText:
Vermonters can get together with friends and family, but should keep groups small whenever possible to limit any possible exposure, and follow health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
Choose other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions. A trusted household is one that has taken seriously the importance of following the general precautions in their day-to-day lives: wearing a cloth face mask or covering, keeping a 6-foot distance from others, washing their hands often, and staying home if they are sick.
Consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of the virus. .
To keep COVID-19 from spreading, we must continue to:

Wear a cloth face mask or covering over your nose and mouth.
Stay home and away from others if you are sick with COVID-19, have recently been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, or just donât feel well.
Keep a 6-foot distance from others when you meet people outside of your household.
Wash your hands frequently (use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol when soap and water are not available).
Cough and sneeze into your elbow (even if you are wearing a cloth face mask or covering).
Limiting travel to within Vermont to the extent possible and when you do travel, limit non-essential stops.

The risk for severe illness increases with age and is higher for older adults and people of any age with certain underlying medical conditions. They should stay close to home, and family and friends should do everything they can to help keep them safe.

questionOriginal: How is Vermont deciding when it is safe to reopen?
questionText: How is Vermont deciding when it is safe to reopen?
answerOriginal:
Most recent modeling data suggests Vermont has reached its peak in the number of new cases of COVID-19, hospital capacity, and the number people who are currently infected with COVID-19.

However, it is important to remember that not everyone infected with the virus has symptoms and there are still many people who are currently infected and could spread it to others.

Vermont is looking at four key measures to inform steps to reopen:

  • Ongoing reduction in cases for at least 14 days
  • A health care system that is safely able to treat all patients without exceeding its capacity or using crisis standards of care
  • The ability to test all people with symptoms
  • Widespread active monitoring of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 and tracing their close contacts

At this time, Vermont continues to do well in keeping the number of cases of COVID-19 down. This is hopeful news. To continue on this path, it is critical that Vermonters continue to follow the general precautions to keep the virus from spreading and to help save lives: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

Read the latest Vermont COVID-19 modeling projections from the Vermont Department of Financial Regulation.

questionOriginal: How does COVID-19 spread?
questionText: How does COVID-19 spread?
answerOriginal:
The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.

  • Between people who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet).

  • Through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs, sneezes or talks.

  • These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs.

  • Some recent studies have suggested that COVID-19 may be spread by people who are not showing symptoms.

It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

Learn from the CDC how to help prevent spread of the virus and how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.
answerText:
The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person, by respiratory droplets released when an infected person talks, coughs, or sneezes. Another person can become infected if the droplets land in their mouth or nose and possibly if the droplets are inhaled into the lungs. The virus might also spread to a personâs hands from a contaminated surface and then to their nose, mouth, or possibly their eyes. Not everyone infected with the virus has symptoms.
There is growing scientific evidence that smaller particles of the COVID-19 virus in the air indoors can infect people. These lighter, finer droplets â that we allÂ exhale from coughing or talking â may stay in the airÂ for several hours, especially when thereâs poor ventilation or overcrowding.
You could become infected if you have indoor contact with those aerosols for an extended period of time.
Follow these general precautions to help prevent the virus from spreading:

Wear a cloth face mask or covering
Keep a 6-foot distance from others
Wash your hands often
Stay home if you are sick.

Learn more from the CDC about how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.

questionOriginal: I have a second home or a seasonal home in Vermont. Can I come to Vermont?
questionText: I have a second home or a seasonal home in Vermont. Can I come to Vermont?
answerOriginal:
If you are a second or seasonal homeowner (including an RV located in Vermont), you are encouraged to stay in your primary home unless you donât have other options. However, the Governorâs Stay Home, Stay Safe Order does not prevent people from going to their seasonal home or RV.

Any individual returning to, or traveling to, Vermont from another state or country for non-essential reasons is required to quarantine at home for 14 days upon their return and before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or going for walks, and must comply with all of the Governorâs Stay Home, Stay Safe Order.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Learn more about quarantine on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.
answerText:
If you are returning to your second or seasonal home in Vermont, you may be required to quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. You are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
If you are coming from certain approved countieswith low rates of active cases, you do not need to quarantine.
All other travelers coming to Vermont must quarantine.
You can either:

Quarantine in your home state for 14 days before coming to Vermont if you are driving in your personal vehicle OR
Quarantine at a lodging facility or Vermont home for 14 days if you are traveling by plane, train, bus or other means of transportation.

You have the option to get tested on Day 7 of your quarantine. Learn more under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
Limit your stops when traveling to Vermont, and only stop when absolutely necessary. When you stop, follow the general precautions: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, and wash your hands often. Stay home and do not travel if you are sick.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

questionOriginal: Where can I get tested for COVID-19?
questionText: Where can I get tested for COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider for a referral. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic for a referral to a test site. If you are having a medical emergency, call 9-1-1 or go to the hospital.

Health care providers are encouraged to order a test for any child or adult who is showing symptoms of COVID-19, even if their symptoms are mild.

Find out what to do if you are sick from the CDC and what to do while youâre waiting for test results.

Pop-up Testing Sites

Any Vermonter without symptoms can be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. This includes people who work in Vermont, second homeowners, and college students. Registration for testing is required. For people who do not have internet access and want to register at a pop-up site, they can call 2-1-1 for help with registration.

Register for a pop-up testing site.

The test is a nasopharyngeal swab, or NP swab, where a health care professional uses a swab to collect a sample from the back of the nose and throat. This test will tell you if you have a current infection. It is not a serology/antibody test, which means it will not tell you if you were infected in the past.

The following groups are encouraged to get tested at pop-up sites: health care workers, first responders (EMS, fire, and law enforcement), child care providers currently serving essential workers, and anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
answerText:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider for a referral. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic for a referral to a test site. If you are having a medical emergency, call 9-1-1 or go to the hospital.
Find out what to do if you are sick from the CDC and what to do while youâre waiting for test results.
Pop-up Testing Sites and Pharmacy Testing Locations
Any person without symptoms who lives or works in Vermont can be tested at no cost at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral.Â This includes people who live in a neighboring state and work in Vermont, second homeowners, and college students. Children under 12 months cannot be tested at a pop-up testing site. Please talk to your childâs doctor about testing options.
Registration for pop-up testing is required. People whoÂ do not have internet access and want to register at a pop-up testing site can call 2-1-1 for help with registration. For pop-up testing site registration questions and issues, call 802-828-2828. If you need transportation to a pop-up testing site, please call 833-387-7200 at least two days before your scheduled appointment.
You will get a call from the Health Department when your results are ready, which is usually within 2 to 4 days, if not sooner. You will also get a letter in the mail within 7 days of being tested.
The test is a nasopharyngeal swab, or NP swab, where a health care provider uses a long swab to collect a sample from the back of the nose and throat. AÂ limited supplyÂ of nasal swabs may be available for children or other priority groups, where a health care provider uses a short swab to collect a sample from the front of the nose. These tests will tell you if you have a current infection. They are not a serology/antibody test, which means the test will not tell you if you were infected in the past.
Some pharmacies may offer testing at no cost for people without symptoms. Call the pharmacy first to see if testing is offered and to schedule an appointment.
Find more information about testing and testing locations.
Some commercial businesses may offer other testing opportunities. You can contact them directly for more information.

questionOriginal: How many people who have tested positive for COVID-19 are in my town or county?
questionText: How many people who have tested positive for COVID-19 are in my town or county?
answerOriginal:
You can find the number of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 by county on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. This map is updated daily.

There is also a map showing the number of Vermonters who have tested positive for COVID-19 by the town where they live. Residents of long-term care facilities and inmates at correctional facilities are included in the town of their facility when they were tested. This map is updated weekly.

The Health Department shares information for towns as a number range. This is to protect the privacy of people who have tested positive for COVID-19. If some information is made public (for example, gender, age, race, health condition, travel history), then a person could be identified, especially if the population of a town is small. This follows both federal and Vermont laws.

The COVID-19 virus is spreading throughout Vermont, and many people may have it and can spread it for up to two days before they show symptoms. It is safe to assume that the virus is in your town or community, and you should take steps to protect yourself and others.

A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.
answerText:
You can find the number of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 by county on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. This map is updated daily.
Below the data dashboard, there is a map showing the number of Vermonters who have tested positive for COVID-19 by the town where they live. Residents of long-term care facilities and inmates at correctional facilities are included in the town of their facility when they were tested. This map is updated weekly.
When looking at the county numbers, please remember that low or no recent cases is not the same as âsafer.â We know the virus is in our communities, and we should continue to follow health guidance to slow the spread of COVID-19 â no matter what county we live in or visit. The map reflects the number of people who had a positive test. There may be active cases in your county that havenât been tested.
A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Why is Vermont testing people who do not have symptoms of COVID-19?
questionText: Why is Vermont testing people who do not have symptoms of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
The CDC issued a recommendation that testing should be occurring at a particular rate per 100,000 people. This is so we can see if the case numbers start to grow again as the state reopens. In Vermont, to achieve that rate, we need to test about 1,000 people per day.

As we test more and more people without symptoms, we are finding fewer and fewer cases. Early on, we only tested people who were very, very ill. Even then, a vast majority did not have COVID-19. Over time we started to test people who were moderately ill, then with mild symptoms, and now we also can include people who do not have symptoms.

Testing helps us better understand the current rate of active infections of COVID-19 in Vermont, and helps to contain and slow the spread to others. It also lets us see how that rate is changing over time as we slowly reopen the state.
answerText:
The CDC issued a recommendation that testing should be occurring at a particular rate per 100,000 people. This is so we can see if the case numbers start to grow again as the state reopens. In Vermont, to achieve that rate, we need to test about 1,000 people per day.
Testing helps us better understand the current rate of active infections of COVID-19 in Vermont, and helps to contain and slow the spread to others. It also lets us see how that rate is changing over time as we continue to reopen the state.

questionOriginal: What is an antigen test?
questionText: What is an antigen test?
answerOriginal:
An antigen test is a newer type of COVID-19 test that identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.

Antigen tests provide results much more quickly than diagnostic, or PCR, tests (the most common type of test used to diagnose COVID-19 infection). But antigen tests may not be as accurate.

Antigen tests may be used to screen people to identify those who need a more definitive test.

We are monitoring how these antigen tests evolve and how results can best be used. Currently, people who test positive from antigen tests are not considered lab-confirmed cases and are not included in our total number of cases. However, we recommend they follow the same guidelines as a positive case to stay home (self-isolate). We would also conduct contact tracing and recommend a more accurate diagnostic test to confirm the positive result.

Antigen tests are different from antibody (serologic) tests, which identify people who have previously been infected with the coronavirus and do not show whether a person is currently infected.
answerText:
An antigen test for COVID-19 is a newer type test that identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus. According to the CDC and the Association of Public Health Laboratories, antigen tests are only recommended for people who have symptoms of COVID-19. So far, studies on antigen tests have only been done on people with symptoms, and we do not have evidence about the accuracy of the antigen test on people without symptoms. More studies are required before antigen testing can be recommended for people without symptoms of COVID-19.
Antigen tests provide results much more quickly than PCR tests (the most common type of test used to diagnose and confirm COVID-19 infection). When used appropriately to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, antigen tests have a higher chance of missing an active infection than PCR tests. This means that if you have symptoms, you may receive a negative result but still be infected with COVID-19.
Antigen tests may be used to screen people to identify those who need a more definitive test.
We are monitoring how these antigen tests evolve and how results can best be used. Right now, people who test positive from antigen tests are not considered to have a lab-confirmed case of COVID-19 and are not included in our total number of cases. However, we consider these cases âpresumptive positivesâ and recommend they follow the same guidelines as a positive case to stay home (self-isolate). We also conduct contact tracing and recommend a PCR test to confirm the positive result.
Antigen tests are different from antibody (serologic) tests, which identify people who have previously been infected with the coronavirus and do not show whether a person is currently infected.
Learn more:

Coronavirus testing basics from the Food & Drug Administration
Considerations for Implementation of SARS-CoV-2 Rapid Antigen Testing from the Association of Public Health Laboratories.

questionOriginal: Are there any travel restrictions into Vermont? Are out-of-state visitors allowed?
questionText: Are there any travel restrictions into Vermont? Are out-of-state visitors allowed?
answerOriginal:
Visitors from other states, and countries, are still being asked not to come to Vermont. If they do, they are required to quarantine at home for 14 days after arriving in Vermont and before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or going for walks.

Anyone who leaves Vermont for more than one day for travel that is not âessential" is required to quarantine at home for 14 days after arriving in Vermont and before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or going for walks.

Essential travel is defined as travel required for personal safety; food, beverage or medicine; medical care; care of others; and to perform work, services or functions deemed critical to public health and safety, as well as economic and national security. Read Addendum 6 for more details.

For those who are in a 14-day quarantine, you may need to rely on neighbors, friends or family living outside of the household to deliver groceries to your home. Check your local grocery store to see if there is an option for home delivery or look for online sources for home delivery. Groceries should always be left at your door. Wash your hands before and after if a signature for receipt is required.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Learn more about quarantine on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.

Read Addendum 7 and Addendum 13 for more information about travel into Vermont.
answerText:
If you are visiting or returning to Vermont you may need to quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. Staying in and completing quarantine is extremely important to help keep people from spreading the virus when they may not know they have it. We strongly encourage you to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
If you are coming from certain approved counties with low rates of active cases, you do not need to quarantine
All other travelers coming to Vermont must quarantine.
You can either:

Quarantine in your home state for 14 days before coming to Vermont if you are driving in your personal vehicle OR
Quarantine at a lodging facility or Vermont home for 14 days if you are traveling by plane, train, bus or other means of transportation.

You have the option to get tested on Day 7 of your quarantine. Learn more under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
Limit your stops when traveling to Vermont, and only stop when necessary. When you stop, follow the general precautions: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, and wash your hands often. Stay home and do not travel if you are sick.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

questionOriginal: What is a PCR test?
questionText: What is a PCR test?
answerOriginal:
A PCR test is the most common type of COVID-19 test used today. PCR stands for polymerase chain reaction. The test identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.

PCR tests are generally the most reliable tests. Samples are analyzed at a lab, which usually takes up to a few days. A PCR test is used at pop-up testing sites offered by the Health Department.

Data on COVID-19 activity reported by the Health Department includes only PCR tests.

The PCR test used by the Vermont Department of Health Laboratory has a sensitivity rate of 95%, which means the test correctly gives a positive result 95% of the time. Sensitivity rates may be different at other labs.
answerText:
A PCR test is the most common type of COVID-19 test used today. PCR stands for polymerase chain reaction. The test identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.
PCR tests are generally the most reliable tests. Samples are analyzed at a lab, which usually takes up to a few days. A PCR test is used at pop-up testing sites offered by the Health Department.
Data on COVID-19 activity reported by the Health Department includes only PCR tests.
The PCR test used by the Vermont Department of Health Laboratory has a sensitivity rate of 95%, which means the test correctly gives a positive result 95% of the time. Sensitivity rates may be different at other labs.

questionOriginal: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again?
questionText: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again?
answerOriginal: The immune response to COVID-19 is not yet understood. Patients with another type of coronavirus, MERS-CoV (also known as MERS) are unlikely to be re-infected shortly after they recover, but it is not yet known whether this is true for people sick from COVID-19.
answerText:
It is not yet known if people whoÂ recoverÂ from COVID-19 can get infected again.
There is also no evidence that people who have recovered from COVID-19 can infect others.

questionOriginal: Are children more susceptible to the COVID-19 virus? How can I help my children from getting sick?
questionText: Are children more susceptible to the COVID-19 virus? How can I help my children from getting sick?
answerOriginal:
No. Based on available evidence, children do not appear to be at higher risk for COVID-19 than adults. While some children and infants have been sick with COVID-19, adults make up most of the known cases to date. You can encourage your child to help stop the spread of COVID-19 by teaching them to do the same things everyone should do to stay healthy.

  • Socialize with household members or one other trusted household that is also taking health and safety precautions.

  • Wash hands often using soap and water or hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.

  • Avoid people who are sick (coughing and sneezing).

  • Clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces daily in household common areas (like tables, hard-backed chairs, doorknobs, light switches, remotes, handles, desks, toilets, sinks).

  • Wash items including washable plush toys, according to the manufacturerâs instructions. If possible, wash items using the warmest appropriate water setting for the items and dry items completely. Dirty laundry from a person who is sick can be washed with other peopleâs items.

As of May 6, Vermonters are now allowed to gather in small groups of 10 or fewer people as long as health and safety precautions are followed. Members of one household may now choose to socialize â and allow children to play â with members of another trusted household that is also taking health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

Find more resources for families with children and information from the CDC on caring for young children.
answerText:
No. Based on available evidence, children do not appear to be at higher risk for COVID-19 than adults. While some children and infants have been sick with COVID-19, adults make up most of the known cases to date. However, a few children have developed multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-C). Currently, information about MIS-C is limited, and the CDC is working to learn more.
You can encourage your child to help stop the spread of COVID-19 by teaching them to do the same things everyone should do to stay healthy.

Stay home if you are sick and avoid people who are sick.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering.
Keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part of your household.
Wash hands often using soap and water (or hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol).
Socialize with household members or other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions.
Clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces daily in household common areas (like tables, hard-backed chairs, doorknobs, light switches, remotes, handles, desks, toilets, sinks).
Wash items including washable plush toys, according to the manufacturerâs instructions. If possible, wash items using the warmest appropriate water setting for the items and dry items completely. Dirty laundry from a person who is sick can be washed with other peopleâs items.

Vermonters can get together with friends and family, but are encouraged to keep groups small when possible to limit any possible exposure to the virus and to keep it from spreading and to follow health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
Find more resources for families with children and information from the CDC on caring for young children.

questionOriginal: Why is it okay to end quarantine after seven days with a negative test result?
questionText: Why is it okay to end quarantine after seven days with a negative test result?
answerOriginal: Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by Day 7. This why there is the option for people to be tested at Day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine. The test must be a PCR test.
answerText: Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by Day 7. This why there is the option for people to be tested at Day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine. The test must be a PCR test.

questionOriginal: Are there any travel restrictions if I am traveling through Vermont?
questionText: Are there any travel restrictions if I am traveling through Vermont?
answerOriginal: If you are only traveling through and not staying in Vermont (for example, driving through Vermont to another state, flying to Vermont and immediately picking up a rental car to drive to another state), there are no quarantine or other restrictions you need to follow. If you need to make stops in Vermont or are otherwise not in a vehicle while you are traveling through Vermont, please follow these general precautions to help prevent the spread of the virus: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, and wash your hands often.

If you need to make stops in Vermont or are otherwise not in a vehicle while you are traveling through Vermont, please follow these general precautions to help prevent the spread of the virus: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, and wash your hands often.

questionOriginal: Is there a rapid (fast) test for COVID-19?
questionText: Is there a rapid (fast) test for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Vermont will soon have a has a limited supply of rapid COVID-19 test machines and supplies. These tests take about 15 minutes for results. Currently, the Health Department is confirming the accuracy of these new tests to detect COVID-19 before they are used. Once they are validated, the Health Department will determine the best locations for these testing machines based on a number of factors. Potential locations could include hospitals, small facilities experiencing a COVID-19 outbreak, and new testing sites.
answerText: There are a few different types of COVID-19 tests, and some are faster than others. The tests also look for different information. If you think you need to be tested for COVID-19, talk with your health care provider about what testing might be appropriate. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic. Get more information about the COVID-19 tests that are currently available from the Food and Drug Administration.

questionOriginal: When will I receive my test results?
questionText: When will I receive my test results?
answerOriginal:
Test results will be available typically within 1 to 3 days.

How you receive results varies depending on where you were tested.

If you were tested at a Health Department popup testing site (for people without symptoms), you will get a call from the Health Department when your results are ready, which is usually within 2 to 4 days, if not sooner. You will also get a letter in the mail within 7 days of being tested. Health Department tests sites are listed here.

If you got tested anywhere else, the Health Department cannot provide your results. Please contact your health care provider if they ordered the test, or the facility that conducted the test.

If you received a positive result, the Health Department will also reach out to talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.
