questionOriginal: How can I get help finding a health care provider?
questionText: How can I get help finding a health care provider?
answerOriginal: 2-1-1 lists community clinics and hospital-connected clinics around the state. 2-1-1 does not list individual primary care providers in their database. If you need a health care provider referral, contact your health care insurer.

Vermont 2-1-1 listsÂ community clinics and hospital-connected clinics around the state and can connect you with one if you do not have a health care provider.
Vermont 2-1-1 does not list individual primary care providers. If you need a health care provider referral, contact your health care insurer.

questionOriginal: How can children socialize while still preventing the spread of COVID-19?
questionText: How can children socialize while still preventing the spread of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
When children are socializing, itâs best for them to keep at least 6 feet away from people they do not live with and to avoid places where they may be close to other people. Itâs also important for parents â and children over 2 who are able â to wear cloth face masks or coverings when youâre around people you do not live with. Learn more about face coverings for children.

If you choose to socialize with family, friends and neighbors, choose other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions and keep groups small whenever possible. A trusted household is one that has taken seriously the importance following these general precautions in their day-to-day lives: wearing cloth face masks or coverings, keeping a 6-foot distance from others, washing their hands often, and staying home if they are sick.

Choose outdoor activities where itâs easy to maintain a 6-foot distance. Remember that ticks are active this time of year. Learn how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites.

Continue to take advantage of technology to play games or keep in touch with friends and family who you are not meeting up with in person. These changes will continue to be difficult, but we are all doing our part to slow down this pandemic.

Most people who get sick from COVID-19 â including children â will experience mild symptoms and recover, but following the general precautions will help us limit the virusâs spread to our vulnerable populations.

Find more resources for families with children.

questionOriginal: Are there resources available to help with home schooling?
questionText: Are there resources available to help with home schooling?
answerOriginal:
There is programming for PreK through 12th grade that is aligned to nationalâand customized to Vermontâstandards. The programming available from a partnership with the Agency of Education and Vermont PBS includes interactive lessons and paired suggested activities for educators, students and families. There are also resources available that allow teachers and caregivers to access at-home curriculum that includes activities, assignments and learning objectives.

The programming will be available for the rest of the school year. It is available on all cable systems and for free over the air through a digital antenna without the need for cable subscription or broadband internet access.

Find the programming schedule and resources for educators, parents and caregivers from Vermont PBS.

Find additional strategies and resources for educators and families from the Agency of Education.

questionOriginal: Is it okay to travel within the United States? Do I need to quarantine when I return?
questionText: Is it okay to travel within the United States? Do I need to quarantine when I return?
answerOriginal:
Cases of COVID-19 have been reported in all states, and some areas are experiencing community spread of the disease. Travel increases your chances of getting and spreading COVID-19.

The CDC recommends you stay home as much as possible, especially if your trip is not essential, and practice social distancing especially if you are at higher risk of severe illness. Donât travel if you are sick or travel with someone who is sick.

In Vermont, people from other states and countries are still being asked not to visit. If they do, they are required to self-quarantine for at least 14 days after arriving in Vermont before engaging in any activities, such as grocery shopping or going for walks.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration is required. Find more details under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

Learn more about quarantine on the what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation chart.
answerText:
COVID-19 cases and deaths have been reported in all 50 states, and the situation is constantly changing. Travel increases your chances of getting and spreading COVID-19. According to the CDC, staying home is the best way to protect yourself and others from getting sick. Donât travel if you are sick or travel with someone who is sick. Read the CDCâs considerations for travelers if you are thinking of traveling away from your local community.
Vermonters may travel toÂ certain counties with low rates of active cases. If you make your trip in a personal vehicle, you do not need to quarantine upon return to Vermont.Â If you travel out of state to a location other than thoseÂ counties with low rates of active cases, you must quarantine in VermontÂ forÂ 14 daysÂ upon return. This includes day trips.
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested with a PCR test. Find out how under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do when you return to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

questionOriginal: Do I need to quarantine if I work in a neighboring state or have parental shared custody?
questionText: Do I need to quarantine if I work in a neighboring state or have parental shared custody?
answerOriginal:
No. If you live near a border and regularly travel to and from a neighboring state, you may make day trips to that state for work, health care, and other essential needs like groceries or visitation for parental shared custody, without quarantining.

However, if you come in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19, you should self-quarantine for 14 days, no matter where the contact occurred. Learn more about what to do if youâre a close contact of someone with COVID-19.

If you travel out of state for another reason and to a location that is not in an approved county with low rates of active cases, you must quarantine for 14 days in Vermont upon return. This includes day trips. Find up-to-date information about travel and COVID-19.

Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested with a PCR test. Find out how under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

questionOriginal: How can I make my own homemade cloth face mask or covering?
questionText: How can I make my own homemade cloth face mask or covering?
answerOriginal:
Homemade cloth face masks or coverings can be made using simple materials found in most homes. For example, an old t-shirt or bandanna and rubber bands or hair ties. Your cloth face mask or covering should include multiple layers of fabric and allow you to be able to breathe easily. Watch a quick video by the CDC on how to make your own cloth face mask.

As the state continues to reopen, it is more important than ever to make wearing cloth face masks or coverings a habit and to bring one with you whenever you leave home. Cloth face masks or coverings need to be worn in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, visiting a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.

Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Do I need to quarantine if someone I had close contact with is under quarantine?
questionText: Do I need to quarantine if someone I had close contact with is under quarantine?
answerOriginal:
No. You do not need to quarantine if you had close contact with someone who is under quarantine.

If you are living with someone who is under quarantine, stay at least 6 feet from them. People under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.

questionOriginal: When can I stop self-isolating (home isolation)?
questionText: When can I stop self-isolating (home isolation)?
answerOriginal:
People with COVID-19 who have stayed home (home isolated) can stop home isolation under the following conditions:

If you will not have a test to determine if you are still contagious, you can leave home after these three things have happened:

  • you have had no fever for at least 72 hours (that is three full days of no fever without the use medicine that reduces fevers) AND

  • other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND

  • at least 10 days have passed since your symptoms first appeared

If you will be tested to determine if you are still contagious, you can leave home after these three things have happened:

  • you no longer have a fever (without the use medicine that reduces fevers) AND

  • other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND

  • you received two negative tests in a row, 24 hours apart.

Your doctor will follow CDC guidelines. In all cases, follow the guidance of your health care provider and the Health Department. The decision to stop home isolation should be made in consultation with your health care provider and the Health Department.
answerText:
People with COVID-19 who have stayed home (home isolated) can stop home isolation under the following conditions:
If you had symptoms, you can leave home and be with others after these three things have happened (unless otherwise instructed by your health care provider:

you have had no fever for at least 24 hours without the use medicine that reduces fevers AND
other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND
at least 10 days have passed since your symptoms first appeared

If you did not have any symptoms, you can leave home and be with others after:

10 days have passed since the date you had your positive test (unless otherwise instructed by your health care provider).

Your health care provider will follow CDC guidelines. In all cases, follow the guidance of your health care provider and the Health Department. The decision to stop home isolation should be made in consultation with your health care provider and the Health Department.
After stopping home isolation, continue to follow the general precautions to help keep the virus from spreading:Â wear aÂ cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others you donât live with, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

questionOriginal: I traveled internationally or by cruise ship. Do I or my household members need to quarantine?
questionText: I traveled internationally or by cruise ship. Do I or my household members need to quarantine?
answerOriginal:
If youâve returned from international travel or from a cruise ship or river cruise voyage, you must quarantine for 14 days. Other members of your household who did not travel do not need to quarantine, but should observe themselves for symptoms for 14 days. Learn about isolation, quarantine and self-observation.

If you or your household members develop symptoms of COVID-19, contact your health care provider right away. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic.

Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

Find more information from the CDC about returning from international travel and returning from cruise ship and river cruise voyages.

Stay up to date on the latest COVID-19 travel advisories from the CDC.

questionOriginal: Do I need a negative COVID-19 test result to return to work safely?
questionText: Do I need a negative COVID-19 test result to return to work safely?
answerOriginal:
A negative test for COVID-19 should NOT be required to return to work. The Health Department does not issue letters for employees to return to work either.

The best way to know when itâs safe for someone who tested positive for COVID-19 to return to work is to follow guidance based on the presence of symptoms, or the amount of time that has passed since the person was tested. This information is found in the employer guidance, under âWhen can employees with COVID-19 return to work?â

This information is found in the employer guidance, under âWhen can employees with COVID-19 return to work?â

questionOriginal: What do I do if I believe I had close contact with someone who has COVID-19?
questionText: What do I do if I believe I had close contact with someone who has COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you have been in close contact with a person who tested positive for COVID-19, monitor yourself for symptoms. This includes checking your temperature every day, watching for symptoms and staying home.

If you develop symptoms of COVID-19 and are a close contact of someone who tested positive, you should:

  1. Call your health care provider and

  2. Call the Vermont Department of Health at 802-863-7240.

If you do not develop symptoms, you do not need to call the Health Department.

Read what to do if you're a close contact of someone with COVID-19.
answerText:
If someone tests positive for COVID-19, they are contacted by the Health Department. They are asked questions about their activities within a certain timeframe â to help identify anyone they had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than 6 feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious. Other factors, such as the nature of the contact with the person, can influence who is determined a close contact.) This is called contact tracing.
If the Health Department determines that you were a close contact of the person who tested positive, then the Health Department will call you to tell you what you need to do.
If the Health Department determines you are not a close contact, then you will not be called. While contact tracers work to identify all close contacts, all might not be identified. If you think that you might be a close contact but didn't get a call from the Health Department, you may take precautions by quarantining for 14 days since the last day you were in contact with that person, and get tested on day 7 or after if you have not had any symptoms.
If you are not a close contact of a person who tested positive, you can continue to take the general precautions to slow the spread of the virus: wear a face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others you do not live with, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

questionOriginal: What is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?
questionText: What is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?
answerOriginal:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part your household. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces and group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes).

Wearing face masks or coverings helps keep people from spreading the virus. This is because the virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms.

In addition to wearing cloth face masks or coverings, everyone should keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.

A face mask or covering must be worn properly to be effective and avoid the spread of germs:

  • Wash your hands before putting it on.
  • Be sure your mouth and nose are covered.
  • Hook loops around your ears or tie it snugly.
  • Do not touch it or pull it down while in public.
  • Keep it on until you get home.
  • Remove it without touching your eyes, nose or mouth, then wash your hands immediately.
  • Wash it and make sure itâs completely dry before using again. Have a few on hand so you can rotate for washing.

If you feel like you are overheating and are having trouble breathing because it is hot outside, you should take off your mask, drink water, rest and seek shade or a cool place. It is important that you keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible, especially when you are not wearing a mask.

Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19 and face coverings for children.

questionOriginal: What is the Health Department doing?
questionText: What is the Health Department doing?
answerOriginal:
The Vermont Department of Health is working closely with long-term care facilities and other group living facilities to prepare for COVID-19 cases and prevent outbreaks, by reviewing CDC guidance for infection control and supporting development of strategies and plans. If cases occur in these settings, the Vermont Department of Health helps the facility implement control measures and prevent additional cases.

The Department does contact tracing to investigate possible travel or exposure history and to identify anyone who had close contact with the person who has tested positive for COVID-19. Those individuals will be assessed for their exposure risk and provided with guidance for their health. Where appropriate, they will receive recommendations for self-isolation or other restrictions. Please note, the Health Department only uses a live person for contact tracing and never uses anything that sounds like a âroboâ (computer-generated voice) call.

Find up-to-date information on the Health Department's COVID-19 website.
answerText:
The Health Department has put into place appropriate measures to protect businesses and Health Department staff. Emergencies and foodborne outbreak investigations are still being responded to during the COVID-19 pandemic.
If you have a complaint about a restaurant, you can submit an illness or sanitation complaint online, email FoodLodging@vermont.gov, or call 802-863-7221. Any complaint received about a food establishment not complying with the Governorâs orders is forwarded to the Office of the Attorney General for enforcement.

questionOriginal: Are face masks or coverings required in Vermont?
questionText: Are face masks or coverings required in Vermont?
answerOriginal:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part your household. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces and group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes).

Face masks or coverings are not required when you are doing strenuous exercise or activities. They are also not required for â and should not be worn by:

  • Children under the age of 2
  • Anyone who has trouble breathing
  • Anyone who is unable to remove the face mask without assistance
  • Anyone who has a medical or behavioral reason for not wearing a face mask

If you have a medical or developmental condition or have trouble breathing, you are not required to show evidence or documentation of your condition.

Businesses and other entities may also post signage explaining their mask requirements and can deny entry or service to people who do not to wear a mask.

Wearing face masks or coverings helps keep people from spreading the virus. This is because the virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms.

In addition to wearing cloth face masks or coverings, everyone should keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.

Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19 and face coverings for children.

questionOriginal: Do homemade cloth face masks or coverings work?
questionText: Do homemade cloth face masks or coverings work?
answerOriginal:
As the state continues to reopen, it is more important than ever to make wearing cloth face masks or coverings a habit and to bring one with you whenever you leave home. Cloth face masks or coverings need to be worn in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain. For example, visiting a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.

Wearing a homemade cloth face mask or covering can offer some protection to others. This is because people may be infected with COVID-19 and not show symptoms for up to two days (48 hours). The cloth face mask or covering can contain respiratory droplets and prevent them from spreading to others.

While health care workers may be able to use homemade cloth face masks or coverings as a last resort, medical-grade masks are considered personal protective equipment. These should be reserved for health care workers.

Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19.
